(m)  At the meeting in question, and after a full hearing of the member's reason for activity, a secret ballot of the review board shall be held to determine on the following actions: 
(1)  Exonerate member(s) of all charges. 
(2)  Terminate member(s) from membership. 
(3)  Place member(s) on three (3) months' probation with all privileges revoked for said time period. 
(n)  The findings of the review board shall be forwarded to the Everman EMS supervisor, with or without recommendations, and shall review the circumstances and findings reported by the review board with the city manager, who shall have the option of deciding the final action to be taken. 
(o)  The majority of the voting members shall decide on the action to be taken on any business matter involving volunteer service members' activities exclusive of the ambulance service volunteer operation. 
(p)  All drivers must be twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. V, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 2.5-26. - Meetings. 
(a)  The Everman EMS volunteers shall hold at least one (1) monthly business meeting conducted by the elected president and attended by the Everman EMS supervisor. 
(b)  All meetings shall be recorded by the secretary/treasurer. 
(c)  Training meetings may be called by the Everman EMS supervisor as deemed necessary and shall be for the purpose of training only. 
(d)  The December meeting shall be known as "the annual meeting" and shall allow the installation of new officers for the coming year. 
(e)  A quorum at any meeting of the Everman EMS volunteers shall consist of a majority of the membership and is required to transact any business. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. VI, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 2.5-27. - Team leaders. 
(a)  The Everman EMS supervisor shall appoint a team leader for each ambulance crew, based upon recommendations from the volunteer membership. A member's appointment as a team leader shall be then decided upon his or her leadership qualities, training, medical service, as described in section 2.5-22, and acting in the highest professional and ethical manner. All appointments are subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the team leader and crew on duty to respond to the station when an emergency call is received from the police dispatcher to assure the ambulance responds to the scene. After arriving on the scene, the team leader shall have the option of declining transport, as outlined in the SOPs. The team leader shall assume complete authority over the operation of the vehicle, actions of crew members and/or any and all conditions arising while said team leader is on duty. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. VII, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 2.5-28. - Boards and committees. 
(a)  Any board, review board or committee may be created or established, based upon need or cause, to carry out any volunteer function exclusive of ambulance service operations and shall be by majority vote of volunteer members. All boards or committees shall be chaired by the president in cooperation with the EMS supervisor. In the event of infractions by volunteers of standard operating procedures and protocol, the EMS supervisor shall attend and be present at all review board hearings for the benefit of any and all information presented. 
(b)  All boards and committees shall be dissolved upon the completion of their designated purpose. 
(c)  There shall be no regular or standing boards or committees. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. VIII, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 2.5-29. - Equipment generally. 
(a)  There shall be no disposal of squad property made without the authority of the city manager. 
(b)  In case of property donated to the squad, it shall be accepted with the understanding that it will be used as any other property belonging to the squad. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. IX, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 2.5-30. - Order of business at meetings. 
The order of business at regularly scheduled meetings shall be as follows: 
(1)  Opening prayer; 
(2)  Roll call; 
(3)  Recognition of any guests; 
(4)  Reading of minutes of last meeting; 
(5)  Committee reports; 
(6)  Old business; 
(7)  New business; 
(8)  Adjournment. 
(Ord. No. 389, Art. X, 6-14-88)  
Chapter 3 - ANIMALS AND ANIMAL CONTROL REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 712, § 3, adopted Sept. 12, 2017, repealed the former Ch. 3, §§ 3-1—3-203, and § 2(Att. A) thereof enacted a new Ch. 3 as set out herein. The former Ch. 3 pertained to animals and derived from Ord. No. 354, adopted June 10, 1986, as amended. See the Code Comparative Tables for comprehensive derivation. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Preamble. 
The animal control regulations as established in this chapter have been adopted for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the city. This chapter contains standards regulating the use, type, location, maintenance, registration, confinement, destruction and harboring of certain animals. The intent of these regulations, prohibitions and provisions is to protect values within the city, to enhance the quality of life of persons, pets, and other animals and to protect the general public from damage and injury which may be caused by unregulated animals. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-2. - Definitions. 
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms, unless the context indicates a different meaning, shall be interpreted as follows: 
Abandoned animal means any animal that: 
(1)  Is left unattended for a period greater than twenty-four (24) hours on private property, thereby creating a threat to the animal's health; 
(2)  Has not been provided with one (1) or more of the necessities of life, including air, food, water or protection from the sun and other elements of nature; 
(3)  Has been released on public or private property with intent to discontinue care or to desert the animal; or 
(4)  Has been left in the custody of another person without such person's consent. 
Animal care and control center means a facility designated and/or operated by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals held under authority of this chapter. 
Animal control authority means the city animal control department which has authority over the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and referenced state law in the city and throughout areas over which it has jurisdiction. 
Animal control officer means any person designated by the city as the primary enforcement officers of ordinances regulating animals and owners of animals and for the enforcement of sections of the Texas Statutes pertaining to the care and control of animals. 
Animal cruelty means to mistreat through intentional or knowing abuse, such as overloading, overworking, tormenting, beating, mutilating or teasing or other abnormal treatment as shall be determined by an animal control officer, or neglect, including abandonment or failure to provide basic care, of any animal in a manner that causes or is likely to cause stress or physical injury, as provided in V.T.C.A. Penal Code § 42.11, or as otherwise stated in this chapter. 
At large. 
(1)  Off-premises: 
a.  Any animal, except a cat, which is not restrained by means of a leash or chain of sufficient strength and length to control the actions of such animal while off the owner's premises. 
b.  Any cat which is off the owner's property. 
(2)  On-premises: Any animal not confined on the premises of the owner by a substantial fence of sufficient strength and height to prevent the animal from escaping therefrom. A dog intruding upon the property of another person other than the owner shall be deemed "at large." Any animal within an automobile or other vehicle of its' owner or owner's agent shall not be deemed "at large" except when left in such an automobile or vehicle in a manner that would not prevent that animal's escape or contact with other persons or animals. 
Basic care means to provide any animal in a person's custody or control with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, adequate shelter and protection from the weather, adequate space, humane care and treatment and reasonable veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering. 
Bite means any abrasion, puncture, or tear of the skin actually caused or suspected of being caused by the teeth or claws of any animal. 
Board means the Texas State Board of Health. 
Dangerous dog means a dog that: 
(1)  Makes an unprovoked attack on a person, that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(2)  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own, and those acts cause a person reasonably to believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person; or 
(3)  Makes an unprovoked attack on a domesticated animal that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and which enclosure was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(4)  Is owned or harbored primarily, or in part, for the purpose of dog fighting, or that has been trained for dog fighting; or 
(5)  Has previously been declared to be a dangerous dog by the animal control authority or any equivalent designation made by any governmental entity or court. 
Dangerous wild animal means as defined in V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code § 822.101. 
Dog means a domesticated animal that is a member of the canine family. 
Domestic animal includes all species of animals commonly and universally accepted as being domesticated. 
Estray means any stray horse, stallion, mare, gelding, filly, colt, mule, jenny, jack, jennet, hog, sheep, goat, fowl, or any species of cattle. 
Exotic species means any mammal, amphibian, reptile or fowl, which is not naturally tame or gentle, and is generally not found in the wild in the continental United States, and those regulated and defined by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Code as exotic (excluding nonvenomous reptiles and fish). 
Exotic livestock/ratites means any species classified as exotic livestock by the Texas Animal Health Commission. 
Harboring means the act of providing any animal with food, water, or shelter, keeping and caring for an animal or providing a premises to which the animal returns for food, shelter, or care. 
Owner means any person or entity owning, having a property interest, keeping, or harboring one (1) or more animals. 
Pet animal means any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility and shall include dogs, cats, rabbits, rodents, birds, non-poisonous reptiles, and any other species of animal which is sold or retained as a household pet but shall not include skunks, non-human primates, and any other species of wild, exotic, or carnivorous animal that may be further restricted in this chapter. 
Poultry means all domesticated fowl and all game birds which are legally kept in captivity except those classified as exotic livestock/ratite as defined above. 
Proper or secure enclosure means a fenced area or structure that is locked, and is capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; is capable of preventing the escape or release of an animal; is clearly marked as containing a quarantined/dangerous animal; and is in conformance with any additional requirements for enclosures, as established and provided in writing to the owner by the animal control authority. 
Rabies vaccination means the vaccination of a dog, cat or other domestic animal with an anti-rabies vaccine approved by the state department of health and administered by a veterinarian licensed by the state. 
Registered dangerous dog means any dog registered with the city in compliance with V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Chapter 822, Subchapter D, and with the article and sections of this chapter addressing registered dangerous dogs. 
Serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or severe ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment. An offense involving serious bodily injury is a class A misdemeanor with criminal jurisdiction for its enforcement in the Tarrant County Courts. 
Serious injury means bodily injury caused by an animal which produces severe pain, trauma, loss of blood or tissue, and which requires medical treatment of wounds inflicted by the animal, and shall include bodily injury resulting from victim whether human or animal, attempting to escape or prevent contact with injuring animal(s). 
Severe attack means [an attack] in which the animal repeatedly bites or vigorously shakes its victim, and the victim, or a person intervening, has extreme difficulty terminating the attack. 
Severe bite means a puncture or laceration made by an animal's teeth which breaks the skin, resulting in a degree of trauma which would cause most prudent and reasonable people to seek medical care for treatment to the wound, without considerations of rabies prevention alone. 
Stray animal (including estrays) means any animal, for which there is no identifiable owner or harborer, which is found to be at large within the corporate limits of the city. 
Unprovoked, with respect to an attack by an animal, shall include, but not be limited to, the fact that the animal was not hit, kicked, or struck by a person with an object or part of a person's body nor was any part of the animal's body pulled, pinched, or squeezed by a person. 
Veterinarian means any practitioner of veterinary medicine licensed by the state to practice such in Texas. 
Vicious animal means any animal (other than dogs which are covered under Article V, Dangerous Dogs) that constitutes a physical threat by reason of its behavior to human beings or other animals. 
Wild animal means all species of animals which exist in a natural unconfined state and are usually not domesticated. This includes any animal which is part wild animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-3. - Animal control duties; enforcement. 
(a)  The animal control officers of the city shall have the authority to issue citations for any violations of this chapter and any other power or duty stated within the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly prevent, interfere with, or obstruct any animal control officer in the performance of his/her duties. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any lawful order of the local rabies control authority officer or any animal control officer of the city. 
(d)  The local rabies control authority officer or any animal control officer, or any peace officer is authorized to: 
(1)  Kill an animal which poses an imminent danger to a person or property, or a real or apparent immediate necessity exists for the destruction of an animal. 
(2)  Impound an animal which is diseased or endangers the health of a person or another animal. 
(3)  Impound any animal hereinafter designated a continuing public nuisance or found to be running at large or to be a stray within the city. 
(4)  Euthanize an impounded animal if the animal is suffering from injury, disease, or illness. 
(5)  Euthanize any animal suspected of having rabies, or which animal manifests a disposition to bite, when such animal(s) is found at large or found to be a stray after having made a reasonable, but unsuccessful, effort to capture the animal. 
(6)  Euthanize any impounded dangerous animal, unless there is reason to believe that it has an owner, immediately upon impoundment. 
(7)  Euthanize any nursing baby animal, excluding livestock impounded without the mother, where the mother cannot or refuses to provide nutritious milk, to prevent further suffering. 
(8)  Euthanize an animal when an owner no longer wishes responsibility for an animal or believes the animal to be in an ill or injured condition upon the owner signing a waiver, supplied by the animal shelter. An owner may also authorize the adoption of an unwanted animal prior to the expiration of the seventy-two-hour impoundment period by signing a waiver. 
(9)  Euthanize or give to a nonprofit humane organization any impounded animal that is to be destroyed as a result of the animal being impounded for more than seventy-two (72) hours. 
(10)  Authorize the immediate euthanizing of any animal impounded and considered by the animal control officer to be feral or of a nature that would cause injury to a person, except when such animal has inflicted a bite to a human during the preceding ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-4. - Enforcement; entry on private premises, police powers. 
(a)  Any city animal control officer or other authorized employee of the city police department shall have, within the city and other areas within the jurisdiction of the animal control division, all of the powers and authority of peace officers to the extent only, and no further, of enforcing state statutes and regulations, this chapter and other ordinances relating to animals. No person shall interfere in any manner or give false information to the above-stated employees in the performance of their duties. 
(b)  An owner of any animal shall immediately comply with an order to surrender such animal issued by an animal control officer or police officer. 
(c)  If persons keeping animals within the city or other areas within the jurisdiction of the animal control authority, after request of the animal control authority or animal control officer, refuse to permit access to the areas or places of keeping of such animals, the animal control authority or officer may seek the necessary court authorization to enter the premises. 
(d)  Any animal observed by an animal control officer or peace officer, in the officer's opinion, to be in immediate danger of death or serious bodily injury, may be removed from such situation by the quickest and most reasonable means available. It shall be the responsibility of the animal's owner to repair any damage to their property or the property of others caused by the removal of the animal from the dangerous situation. 
(e)  The animal control officer or peace officer has the right to pursue and apprehend animals running at large onto private property while enforcing the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
ARTICLE II. - VACCINATION AND LICENSING 
 
Sec. 3-5. - Dog and cat vaccinations and licenses. 
(a)  Required. All dogs and cats four (4) months of age or older that are kept, harbored or maintained within the corporate limits of the city shall be licensed. Cat and dog licenses shall be issued by the animal control officer or his agent upon payment of the required fee for each cat or dog. The license fee for cats and dogs shall be as set forth in the fee schedule in this chapter. Before a city license will be issued, the owner of the cat or dog must present a certificate from a licensed veterinarian showing that the cat or dog has a current rabies vaccination. Such vaccinations must be in compliance with Article VII, Rabies Control of this chapter. The license shall be good for one (1)year from the date of issuance. 
(b)  Tag or collar. Upon payment of the license fee, the city shall issue to the owner a license certificate and a metal tag having stamped thereon the year for which it is issued and the number corresponding with the number of the certificate. Such tag shall at all times be securely attached to a collar or harness around the neck of the animal. In case a tag is lost, a duplicate will be issued by the animal control officer or his agent upon presentation of the receipt showing the payment of the license fee for the calendar year. Tags shall not be transferable from one (1) animal to another and no refunds shall be made. 
(c)  Revocation of registrations. 
(1)  The animal control authority or any animal control officer may revoke any cat or dog registration after a hearing for any one (1) or more of the following reasons: 
a.  Impoundment of a cat or dog by the city more than three (3) times during a twelve-month period; 
b.  More than three (3) final convictions of a person for violating this chapter when such convictions relate to the cat or dog that is being considered for revocation of its registration certificate; 
c.  Any combination of a. and b. of this subsection totaling three (3) incidents; 
d.  Upon a determination that the cat or dog is a vicious cat or dog, as defined in this chapter; 
e.  If a person falsifies information during the licensing process or refuses or fails to comply with this chapter or any state law or regulation governing the protection of animals, official notice shall be given to the license holder of the intention to suspend the license. If, within seven (7) days after official notice is given, evidence shows the person is not in compliance, the license shall be revoked. 
(2)  Upon revoking the registration of any cat or dog, the animal control officer shall notify the owner of the cat or dog of the action in writing. Written notification shall be deemed made when a certified letter, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known mailing address of the owner of the dog or cat is deposited in the U.S. Mail. 
(3)  Upon the expiration of ten (10) days after written notification or revocation is deposited in the U.S. Mail, as provided in subsection (2) above, no cat or dog that has had its registration revoked shall be kept, maintained, or harbored within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 3-6. - Animals at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, including, but not limited to, the animal's owner, to allow an animal to be at large. The owner of an animal is responsible at all times for ensuring that his or her animal is properly secured or restrained and is not at large. 
(b)  Any officer or citizen of the city is hereby authorized to take up and deliver to the office of the animal control authority any animal mentioned in this chapter that may be found "at large" in the corporate limits of the city, subject to the applicable provisions of the law. Failure to notify and/or turn over to an animal control officer or the animal control authority any such animal within forty-eight (48) hours may subject the person taking up the animal to civil and/or criminal action. 
(c)  The animal control officer or his agent and any peace officer are authorized to impound any animal found to be at large or otherwise in violation of this chapter. If the animal is on private property or property of the animal's owner, the animal control officer, his agent, or a peace officer may enter the property, other than a private dwelling, for the purpose of impoundment or issuance of a citation, or both, subject to the applicable provisions of the law. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-7. - Confinement during estrus. 
Any unspayed female dog or cat in the state of estrus (heat) shall be confined during such period of time in a house, building or other secure enclosure and the area of enclosure shall be so constructed that no other dog or cat may gain access to the confined animal. Owners who do not comply shall be ordered to remove the animal in heat to a boarding kennel, veterinary hospital or animal shelter. All expenses incurred as a result of this confinement shall be paid by the owner. Failure to comply with the removal order of the animal control officer shall be a violation of this chapter and the dog or cat will then be impounded as prescribed in this chapter.  
Sec. 3-8. - Harboring stray animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, without the actual consent of the owner, to harbor, feed, keep in possession by confinement or otherwise have an animal which does not belong to the person unless he/she has, within forty-eight (48) hours, notified the animal control authority. Upon receipt of such notice, the animal control authority may impound the animal and its disposition will be in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-9. - Harboring wild animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any wild animal within the city without a permit, except commercial establishments dealing in the sale of such animals which have proper facilities for the restraint and care thereof. The animal control officer and the city manager or his assistant may issue a permit to allow wild animals to be kept or harbored in the city, and shall establish the conditions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-10. - Number of pets permitted. 
No person shall keep or harbor more than four (4) cats and dogs (when the number of cats and dogs are added together) in one residence or one business. Puppies and kittens under four (4) months of age shall not be counted for purposes of this section. A person fostering animals, including animals from the animal care and control center, must also comply with these limits. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-11. - Abandoned animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of an animal to abandon that animal. Such an offense is a class A misdemeanor in the State of Texas and punishable by up to a four thousand dollar ($4,000.00) fine and/or year in jail. 
(b)  Any owner of an unwanted animal, other than livestock or swine, may relinquish the animal to an animal control officer after paying the required fee and completing an owner release form. Disposition of the animal will be in accordance with this chapter. 
(c)  If an animal control officer finds that an animal has been abandoned, the animal may be impounded. If the animal has been abandoned in a house or within a fenced area, the animal control officer must make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or manager of the property. If the property owner or manager is not the animal's owner, then the animal control officer shall secure permission to remove the animal. If the property owner is also the animal owner and this individual cannot be located, the animal control officer shall secure an appropriate warrant to seize the animal. 
(d)  An animal seized pursuant to this section shall be impounded for a period of one-hundred-twenty (120) hours. If the owner contacts the animal care and control center to reclaim the animal, an explanation for the animal's abandonment must be provided to the satisfaction of the animal control authority before the animal is released to the owner and the release must also be in accordance with this chapter. If the animal is unclaimed its disposition will be in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-12. - Owner must reside on premises with animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause a dog or cat to reside on property where an owner of the animal does not reside or currently operate a business so that the animal is attended to on a regular basis. 
(b)  In the event any person violates this section, the animal control authority may immediately issue a summons for such person to appear in municipal court for a hearing on such charges. If the municipal court judge issues an appropriate order, an animal control officer or the animal control authority may seize the animal and its disposition shall be in accordance with this chapter. In the event the owner of the animal is unknown, or after reasonable diligence the owner cannot be located, an animal control officer or the animal control authority may remove the animal and its disposition shall be in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-13. - Animal cruelty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly: 
(1)  Torture an animal or in a cruel manner kill or cause serious bodily injury to an animal; 
(2)  Fail unreasonably to provide necessary food, basic care and shelter for an animal in the person's custody. An animal enclosure shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair. Plastic air shipping containers and/or pet carriers shall not be used as outdoor shelters; 
(3)  Abandon unreasonably an animal in a person's custody; 
(4)  Transport or confine an animal in a cruel manner; 
(5)  Kill, seriously injure, or administer poison to an animal belonging to another without legal authority or the owner's effective consent, except when an animal is discovered on the person's property in the act of or immediately after injuring or killing livestock, fowl or any domestic animal; 
(6)  Cause one animal or fowl to fight with another; 
(7)  Use a live animal as a lure in dog race training or in a dog coursing on a racetrack; 
(8)  Trip a horse; 
(9)  Seriously overwork an animal; 
(10)  Tether an animal in a manner that causes injury or death; or 
(11)  Allow conditions that cause or permit unwarranted pain and suffering. 
(b)  This section applies to any person in possession of an animal regardless of ownership. It is a defense to prosecution that the conduct engaged in involved self-defense, or is a bona fide scientific experimentation, or is related to wildlife management. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-14. - Guard dogs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place or maintain any dog solely for the protection of persons and/or property unless the dog is physically confined to a specific enclosed area. The enclosed area in which the dog is confined must be with a chain link fence of at least six (6) feet in height and is reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own. 
(b)  The area in which the dog is confined must be conspicuously posted with warning signs bearing letters not less than two (2) inches high, stating "Guard Dog" and placed not less than every twenty-five (25) feet, on each side for the structure or barrier confining the dog(s). No less than one (1) warning sign shall be posted. 
(c)  The fact that a dog is subject to this section shall not relieve the owner of any duties imposed by other provisions in this chapter, including any registration requirement. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-15. - Tampering with traps and equipment. 
No person shall remove, alter, damage, or otherwise tamper with a trap or equipment set out by the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-16. - Animal care. 
(a)  No person shall fail to provide basic care as defined in this chapter for any animal the person owns or that is in his or her custody or control. 
(b)  No person shall give away any live animal, whether as a prize for or as an inducement to, entering any contest, game or other competition or as an inducement to enter a place of business; nor offer such animal as an incentive to enter into any business agreement whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade. 
(c)  Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal shall immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner. If the owner cannot be ascertained and located, then such operator shall at once report the accident to the appropriate law enforcement agency or to the local humane society. 
(d)  No person shall expose an open trap or metal-jaw-type trap that shall be liable to injure any domestic animal or person. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-17. - Unlawful restraint of dog. 
(a)  No person shall leave a dog outside and unattended by use of a restraint that unreasonably limits the dog's movement: 
(1)  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Within five hundred (500) feet of the premises of a school; or 
(3)  In the case of extreme weather conditions, including conditions in which: 
a.  The actual or effective outdoor temperature is below thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  A heat advisory has been issued by a local or state authority or jurisdiction; or 
c.  A hurricane, tropical storm, or tornado warning has been issued for the jurisdiction by the National Weather Service. 
(b)  In this section, a restraint unreasonably limits a dog's movement if the restraint: 
(1)  Uses a collar that is pinch-type, prong-type, or choke-type or that is not properly fitted to the dog; 
(2)  Is a length shorter than the greater of: 
a.  Five (5) times the length of the dog, as measured from the tip of the dog's nose to the base of the dog's tail; or 
b.  Ten (10) feet; 
(3)  Is in an unsafe condition; or 
(4)  Causes injury to the dog. 
(c)  Exceptions. This section does not apply to: 
(1)  A dog restrained to a running line, pulley, or trolley system and that is not restrained to the running line, pulley, or trolley system by means of a pinch-type, prong-type, choke-type, or improperly fitted collar; 
(2)  A dog restrained in compliance with the requirements of a camping or recreational area as defined by a federal, state, or local authority or jurisdiction; 
(3)  A dog restrained for a reasonable period, not to exceed three (3) hours in a twenty-four-hour period, and no longer than is necessary for the owner to complete a temporary task that requires the dog to be restrained; 
(4)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in, or actively training for, an activity that is conducted pursuant to a valid license issued by this state if the activity for which the license is issued is associated with the use or presence of a dog; 
(5)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in conduct directly related to the business of shepherding or herding cattle or livestock; or 
(6)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in conduct directly related to the business of cultivating agricultural products, if the restraint is reasonably necessary for the safety of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-18. - Filing of false claims or reports. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he knowingly initiates, communicates, or circulates a claim of ownership for an animal with the animal control manager that he knows is false or baseless. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he knowingly initiates, communicates, or circulates a report of a violation of city ordinance or state law with the animal control officer that he knows is false or baseless. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-19—3-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC NUISANCE 
 
Sec. 3-25. - Nuisance unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, possess, or maintain an animal, or property housing animals, in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance. By way of example, and not of limitation, the following conditions, events, acts or actions of an owner of an animal are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and are unlawful: 
(1)  Any animal that molests, chases, or attacks passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)  Any animal that molests, chases, or attacks other animals; 
(3)  Any animal that trespasses on school grounds; 
(4)  Any animal that is repeatedly at large (e.g., three (3) or more times per twelve-month-month period) 
(5)  Any animal that damages or defiles private or public property or causes substantial inconvenience to another; 
(6)  Any animal that barks, whines, howls, crows or makes other noise in an excessive, continuous fashion so as to interfere with the reasonable use and enjoyment of neighboring premises. If such noise occurs between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. it shall be prima facie proof that it is unreasonable. It shall be a defense to prosecution if an individual, other than the owner, provokes or taunts the animal. 
(7)  Failing to confine a female dog or cat while in season in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that she cannot come into contact with another dog or cat, or create a nuisance by attracting other animals; provided this section shall not be construed to prohibit the intentional breeding of animals within an enclosed area on the premises of the owner of an animal which is being bred; 
(8)  Any animal that is a dangerous animal or dangerous dog not confined as required by this chapter or an animal that is diseased and dangerous to the public health; 
(9)  Maintaining animals or property in an environment of unsanitary conditions or lack of cleanliness that results in offensive odor or is dangerous to the public health, welfare, or safety or a failure to maintain animals in a condition of good order and cleanliness so as to reduce the probability of transmission of disease; 
(10)  An object, place, or condition (including, but not limited to, fecal matter, garbage or other organic wastes) that is a potential instrument or medium for disease transmission; 
(11)  Any dead animal not lawfully disposed of within twenty-four (24) hours of its death. Requests for disposal of small animals, including dogs and cats, may be made to the animal control authority or animal care and control center. If the animal dies on property owned by another person, the property owner may dispose of the carcass at the expense of the animal's owner. 
(12)  A condition or place that is a breeding ground for flies; 
(13)  A collection of water in which mosquitoes are breeding; 
(14)  A place or condition harboring rats; 
(15)  Any animal which damages, soils, defiles, urinates or defecates on private property other than that of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-26. - Animals for sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to sell, exchange, barter, give away, or offer to sell, exchange barter or give away any animal from a public street, alley, easement, or right-of-way, or from property owned or controlled by a local, county, state or federal governmental entity within the city or other applicable animal control authority jurisdiction. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to sell, exchange, barter, give away, or offer to sell, exchange, barter, or give away any animal on, in, upon, through or from any premises or space upon any private property within the city unless the person resides at such property or has a legal right of occupancy to such property for a period of six (6) months for the purpose of conducting such transactions. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a person to sell, exchange, barter, give away, or offer to sell, exchange, barter, or give away a dangerous animal within the city or other applicable jurisdiction of the animal control authority. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a person to sell, exchange, barter, give away, or offer to sell, exchange, barter, or give away a dangerous dog within the city or other applicable animal control authority jurisdiction except in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-27. - Vicious animals. 
Except for dangerous dogs which may be kept in accordance with article VIII, no person shall own or harbor a vicious animal within the city; such an animal shall be impounded as a public nuisance. If impoundment of said animal cannot be made with safety, the animal may be destroyed without notice to the owner. Any animal which kills another domestic or pet animal or kills or severely maims an individual shall be removed from the city within twenty-four (24) hours following the owner being notified, otherwise, said animal shall be impounded and destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-28. - Authority to destroy injured or diseased animals. 
The city police department, animal control officer, or authorized representative is authorized to destroy any injured or diseased animal, whether such animal is on public or private property, and when the recovery from such injuries or disease is in serious doubt, and after a reasonable effort had been made to locate the owner of such animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-29. - Breeding of livestock. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal listed in the definition of "estray" herein to knowingly permit or cause to be permitted the breeding of any such animal within the public view, whether such animal is on or off the premises of its owner. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-30. - Enclosures. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any horse, cow, cattle, sheep, goat, or fowl within two hundred (200) feet of another person's residence or occupied building, or to keep any swine/pig within five hundred (500) feet of another person's residence or occupied building. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-31—3-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - IMPOUNDMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 3-41. - Impoundment. 
Any animal control officer or other designated official may take up and confine any animal found at large or that is owned or harbored or otherwise treated or kept in a manner or condition that violates this chapter or any other local, state or federal law or regulation. Any impoundment of animals authorized in this chapter shall be performed in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-42. - Disposition of impounded animals. 
(a)  Notice. If the owner of any impounded animal is known, the animal control officer shall attempt to notify him or her not later than twenty-four (24) hours from the beginning of the next business day after such impoundment. 
(b)  Redemption by owner. Any owner of an impounded animal, except an animal that is being held on a complaint for violation of this chapter or other law or that is required to be quarantined, may redeem the animal by complying with all of the requirements of this article and payment of the impoundment fee, care and feeding charges, veterinary charges, rabies vaccination charges and such other costs as set by the animal control officer. 
(c)  If any animal is not redeemed within three (3) days after notification to owner, where owner is known, or after confinement if the owner is not known, it shall be deemed abandoned and may be placed for adoption, subject to payment of an adoption fee; or the animal control officer may humanely euthanize such an animal by injection or other means approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-43. - Disposition of impounded animal being held on complaint. 
If a complaint has been filed in municipal court for the city against the owner of an impounded animal for a violation of this chapter or any other law, the animal shall not be released except on the order of the court, which may also direct the owner to pay any penalties for violation of this chapter, in addition to all impoundment fees. Surrender of an animal by the owner thereof to the animal control officer does not relieve or render the owner immune from the decision of the court, nor to the fees and fines which may result from a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-44. - Removal of animals from confinement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove from any place of confinement any animal which has been confined as authorized, without the consent of the impounding agency. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-45. - Proof of rabies vaccination and tag required for release/second impoundment. 
(a)  If the owner of an impounded cat or dog takes possession of the animal from the animal care and control center, the owner shall provide proof of current rabies vaccination and city tag certification. If the animal does not have a current rabies vaccination and city tag certification, the owner shall have the animal vaccinated and provide proof to the animal control authority of vaccination and city tag certification no later than thirty (30) days after taking possession of the animal. 
(b)  If a cat or dog is impounded a second time, the owner must also sign a thirty-day spay/neuter contract and submit a prepaid surgery receipt from any vet in the area prior to release of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-46—3-65. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ESTRAYS 
 
Sec. 3-66. - Unattended estrays. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow an estray to be unattended upon any public street, alley, or thoroughfare or upon the private property of another in the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The person having ownership or right to immediate control of such estray shall have the burden to keep such estray off the public streets, alleys, and thoroughfares or the property of another in the city. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-67. - Impoundment of estrays. 
It shall be the duty of the animal control officer, in the absence of action by the county sheriff's office, to take up any estray that may be found in and upon any street or alley, or in or upon any unenclosed lot in the city or otherwise to be found at large, and to confine such estray for safekeeping. Upon impounding an estray, the animal control officer shall prepare a "notice of estray" and file such notice in the estray book located in the office of the animal control officer. Each entry shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the person who notified the animal control officer of the estray; 
(2)  The location of the estray when found; 
(3)  The location of the estray until disposition; 
(4)  A description of the animal including its breed, color, sex, age, size, all markings of any kind, and any other identifying characteristics. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-68. - Advertisement of impounded estrays. 
When an estray has been impounded, the animal control officer shall make a diligent search of the register of recorded brands in the county for the owner of the estray. If the search does not reveal the owner, the animal control officer shall advertise the impoundment of the estray in a newspaper of general circulation in the county at least twice during the next fifteen (15) days following impoundment and post a notice of the impoundment of the estray on the public notice board of the city hall. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-69. - Recovery by owner. 
The owner of an estray may recover possession of the animal at any time before the animal is sold under the terms of this article if: 
(1)  The owner has provided the animal control officer with an affidavit of ownership of the estray containing at least the following information: 
a.  The name and address of the owner; 
b.  The date the owner discovered that the animal was an estray; 
c.  The property from which the animal strayed; 
d.  A description of the animal including its breed, color, sex, size, all markings of any kind, and any other identifying characteristics. 
(2)  The animal control officer has approved the affidavit; 
(3)  The affidavit has been filed in the estray book; 
(4)  The owner has paid all estray handling fees to those entitled to receive them; 
(5)  The owner has executed an affidavit of receipt containing at least the following information: 
a.  The name and address of the person receiving the estray; 
b.  Date of receipt of estray; 
c.  Method of claim to estray (owner, purchaser at sale); 
d.  If purchased at sale, the amount of gross purchase price; 
e.  Amount of estray handling fees paid; 
f.  The net proceeds of the sale. 
(6)  The animal control officer has filed the affidavit of receipt in the estray book. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-70. - Fees. 
For each and every estray taken and impounded there shall be paid to the city by the owner thereof or his agents the applicable fees set forth in the fee schedule contained in this chapter for each and every subsequent day that the animal shall remain in the custody of the animal control officer. Such fee being charged for the caring and feeding of such animal. The owner shall also pay for any veterinarian or drug fees incurred for the animal while it is in the custody of the city. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-71. - Sale of estray. 
(a)  If the ownership of an estray is not determined within fourteen (14) days following the final advertisement required by this article, title to the estray rests in the city and the animal control officer shall then cause the estray to be sold at a public auction. 
(b)  Title to the estray shall be deemed vested in the animal control officer for purposes of passing a good title, free and clear of all claims, to the purchaser at the sale. 
(c)  The purchaser of an estray at public auction may take possession of the animal upon payment thereof. 
(d)  The disposition of the proceeds derived from the sale of an estray at public auction will be as follows: 
(1)  Pay all handling fees to those entitled to receive them; 
(2)  Execute a report of sale of impounded stock; 
(3)  The net proceeds remaining from the sale of the estray after the handling fees have been paid shall be delivered by the animal control officer to the city treasurer. Such net proceeds shall be subject to claim by the original owner of the estray as provided in this division; 
(4)  If the bids are too low, the animal control officer shall have the right to refuse all bids and arrange for another public auction or sealed bidding procedure. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-72. - Recovery by owner of sale proceeds. 
Within six (6) months after the sale of an estray under the provisions of this division, the original owner of the estray may recover the net proceeds of the sale that were delivered to the city treasurer if: 
(1)  The owner has provided the animal control officer with an affidavit of ownership; 
(2)  The animal control officer has approved the affidavit; 
(3)  The approved affidavit has been filed in the estray book. 
(4)  After the expiration of six (6) months from the sale of an estray, as provided by this division, the sale proceeds shall escheat to the city. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-73. - Use of estray. 
During the period of time an estray is held by the person who impounded the estray, the estray may not be used by any person for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-74. - Death or escape of estray. 
If the estray dies or escapes while held by the person who impounded it, the person shall report the death or escape to the animal control officer. The report shall be filed in the estray book. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-75—3-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - KENNELS 
 
Sec. 3-96. - Definition. 
As used in this article, "kennel" is defined as any lot or premises on which four (4) or more dogs, cats or other domestic animals at least four (4) months of age are housed or accepted for boarding, trimming, grooming and/or bathing for which remuneration is received. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-97. - Permit—Required. 
A kennel shall not be allowed until a kennel permit is issued by the city. The city animal control officer shall determine, after inspection, whether or not such permit shall be issued. No permit shall be issued for a kennel to operate within one thousand (1,000) feet of any residence. Grooming parlors where no dogs or cats are to be kept overnight and veterinary clinics shall not be considered kennels, nor subject to this article. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-98. - Same—Term; fee. 
Such permits shall be valid for one (1) year from date of issuance. The permit fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-99. - Same—Revocation or suspension. 
Any kennel permitted under this article which is found to be in violation of any zoning law, health law or any other applicable law of the city or the state, or any kennel that is maintained in such a manner as to be detrimental to the health, safety or peace of mind of persons residing in the immediate vicinity, may have its kennel permit suspended or revoked without prior notice by the city animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-100—3-118. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - RABIES CONTROL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 3-119. - Adoption of rabies control measures. 
For the purpose of controlling and eradicating rabies, the city hereby adopts V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Chapter 826 and 25 Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 826 entitled "Zoonosis Control," as such may be amended or revised from time to time. These provisions shall govern all matters covered therein within the city or other area within the jurisdiction of the animal control division of the city, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-120. - Designation of local rabies control authority. 
The city hereby appoints the city animal control director to be the local rabies control authority for the city. The local rabies control authority shall enforce this chapter and other related ordinances of the city, V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Chapter 826, and associated rules and the rules adopted by the executive commissioner under the area rabies quarantine provisions. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-121. - Reporting of rabies and bites or scratches. 
(a)  A person who knows of an animal bite or scratch to an individual that the person could reasonably foresee as capable of transmitting rabies, or who knows of an animal that the person suspects is rabid, shall report the incident or animal to the local rabies control authority of the city within twelve (12) hours of learning of such incident. 
(b)  The report must include: 
(1)  The name and address of the victim and of the animal's owner, if known; and 
(2)  Any other information that may help in locating the victim or animal, including the name, age, sex and precise location of the bitten person and such other information as the police department or animal control officer may require. 
(c)  The local rabies control authority shall investigate a report filed under this section. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-122. - Reporting suspected rabies. 
Every owner, custodian or veterinarian shall report to the local rabies control authority officer or his designee all cases of rabies or suspected rabies of which any of them has knowledge. The dog or cat having rabies or symptoms thereof, or suspected of having rabies, or which has been exposed to rabies, shall immediately be confined for observation and quarantine period. The local rabies control authority shall investigate a report filed under this section. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-123—3-155. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DOGS AND CATS 
 
Sec. 3-156. - Vaccinations. 
The Texas Rabies Control Act (V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code § 826.021) requires all pet owners to vaccinate and keep current the rabies vaccination in dogs or cats that are four (4) months of age and older. Every owner of a dog or cat four (4) months of age or older shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies. All such dogs or cats shall be revaccinated one (1) year after the date of the first vaccination, then annually thereafter if given a one (1) year vaccine or tri-annually thereafter if given a three-year vaccine. 
Any person establishing residence within the city shall comply with this division within ten (10) days of establishing such residency. If an unvaccinated dog or cat inflicts a bite or scratch, or otherwise attacks any person within the city limits, a rabies vaccine shall not be administered to the dog or cat until after a ten-day observation period has transpired, beginning with the date of the bite, scratch or attack. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-157. - Certificate of vaccination. 
(a)  Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall execute and furnish to the owner of the dog or cat, as evidence thereof, a certificate of vaccination. The veterinarian shall retain a duplicate copy of the certificate and one (1) copy shall be filed with the owner. Such certificate shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated dog or cat; 
(2)  The date of vaccination; 
(3)  The type of rabies vaccine used; 
(4)  The year and number of the rabies tag; 
(5)  The breed, age, color, and sex of the vaccinated dog or cat. 
(b)  Information contained in a rabies vaccination certificate or any record compiled from such information shall be confidential as set forth in V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code § 826.0211 and shall not be subject to disclosure under the Texas Public Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-158. - Rabies tag. 
Concurrent with the issuance and delivery of the certificate of vaccination, the owner of the dog or cat shall cause to be attached to the collar or harness of the vaccinated animal a metal tag, serially numbered to correspond with the vaccination certificate number and bearing the year of issuance. The owner of a dog or cat shall ensure that the animal bears this vaccination tag at all times. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-159. - Use and sale of rabies vaccine. 
(a)  Rabies vaccine for animals may be administered only by or under the direct supervision of a veterinarian. 
(b)  A veterinarian may not administer or directly supervise the administration of rabies vaccine in this state unless the person is: 
(1)  Licensed by the state board of veterinary medical examiners to practice veterinary medicine; or 
(2)  Practicing veterinary medicine on an installation of the armed forces or National Guard. 
(c)  A person may not sell or distribute rabies vaccine for animals to any person except a licensed veterinarian or to a person working in a veterinary clinic who accepts the vaccine on behalf of the veterinarian. 
(d)  This section does not prohibit a pharmacy licensed by the Texas State Board of Pharmacy from supplying rabies vaccine for animals to a licensed veterinarian. 
(e)  This section does not prohibit a veterinarian licensed by the Texas State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners from selling or dispensing rabies vaccine to an individual with whom the veterinarian has a veterinarian-client-patient relationship as described by V.T.C.A. Texas Occupations Code Chapter 801, for the sole purpose of allowing that individual to administer the rabies vaccine to that individual's own livestock. 
(f)  A person commits an offense if the person: 
(1)  Administers or attempts to administer rabies vaccine in a manner not authorized by this section; 
(2)  Dispenses or attempts to dispense rabies vaccine in a manner not authorized by this section; 
(3)  Sells or distributes rabies vaccine for animals in violation of this section. 
(g)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-160—3-169. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - QUARANTINE 
 
Sec. 3-170. - Facilities. 
All quarantine and impoundment facilities shall be maintained in accordance with standards established by the V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Chapter 826. Testing of quarantined animals and the procedures for and method of quarantine shall be as set forth in V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code § 826.042 and as set forth below. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-171. - Method and testing. 
(a)  When a dog or cat which has bitten a human being has been identified, the owner shall place the animal in quarantine. The observation period shall begin on the day of the biting. The dog or cat must be placed in the animal care and control center or in a veterinarian facility specified for this purpose; however, the owner of the dog or cat may request permission from the local rabies control authority to home quarantine, if the following criteria can be met: 
(1)  Secure facilities must be available at the home of the dog or its owner, and must be approved by the local rabies control authority or his designee; 
(2)  The dog or cat was vaccinated against rabies prior to the bite; 
(3)  The local rabies control authority or his designee, or a licensed veterinarian must observe the dog or cat at least on the first and last days of the quarantine period. If the dog or cat becomes ill during the observation period of the quarantine, the local rabies control authority must be notified by the person having possession of the dog or cat. At the end of the observation period, the release from quarantine must be accomplished in writing by the local rabies authority or his designee in accordance with this chapter; 
(4)  The dog or cat was not in violation of any provisions of this chapter at the time of the biting incident; and 
(5)  If the dog or cat cannot be maintained in secure quarantine, it shall be humanely destroyed and the brain be submitted to the state department of health's certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
(b)  No wild animal shall be placed in quarantine. All wild animals involved in biting incidents will be humanely destroyed in such a manner that the brain is not mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a state department of health's certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
(c)  Quarantine procedures. 
(1)  Biting animals and animals suspected of rabies that are placed in confinement for observation must be separated from all other animals in such a manner that there is no possibility of physical contact between the animal under quarantine and animals not under quarantine. 
(2)  Unowned or owned animals may be destroyed for rabies diagnosis prior to the end of the quarantine period. 
(3)  The local rabies control authority may require a written agreement from the owner or the custodian of the animal at the time of quarantine agreeing to the terms of quarantine and providing for the disposal of the animal if the terms are violated or if the local rabies control authority deems it necessary at any time during the quarantine period. 
(d)  Quarantine by owner minimum requirements (if approved by the local rabies control authority): 
(1)  The animal must be kept in a secure enclosure and must remain there for ten (10) days. 
(2)  The animal must be kept away from other animals and people except those in the immediate household. 
(3)  The animal may not be removed from the corporate city limits of Everman while under quarantine. 
(4)  The owner shall notify the city animal control division immediately if the animal becomes sick, displays any behavioral changes or dies. 
(5)  The owner shall not subject the animal to any medical procedure (including vaccinations) without first notifying the animal control division. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-172. - Disposition of domestic animals other than dogs and cats exposed to rabies. 
(a)  Any disposition of a domestic animal exposed to rabies shall be in accordance with standards established in the V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Chapter 826. 
(b)  The provisions of this section apply only to common domestic animals, other than a dog or cat, for which an approved rabies vaccine is available. Sufficient justification for quarantine rather than humane destruction of such an animal shall be determined by the local rabies control authority after consulting with two (2) disinterested veterinarians, after hearing the stated grounds for such justification in writing by the owner of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-173. - Violation of quarantine; killing of biting animal prohibited; surrender of carcasses of dead animals suspected of rabies. 
(a)  The violation of any condition of quarantine by any person shall be just cause for the seizure and impoundment of the quarantined animal by the city animal control officer if quarantined at a veterinarian office or at the owner's premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to interrupt the observation period. If a violation of quarantine occurs, it shall be just cause for humane destruction of the animal for the purpose of certified laboratory rabies diagnosis in the event that a person who was bitten by the animal is placed in a position that jeopardizes his health or welfare or if the local rabies control authority determines it is in the interest of public safety. 
(b)  All animal bite reports shall be investigated by the local rabies control authority or his designee. Without the permission of the local rabies control authority or his designee, it shall be unlawful for any person to kill or remove from the city any animal that has bitten a person or attacked or killed another animal, or that has been placed under quarantine, except when it is necessary to kill such animal to protect the life of any person or other animal. If such animal is killed, it shall be reported immediately to the local rabies control authority, an animal control officer, or a licensed veterinarian in order that the animal may be properly handled for the purpose of certified laboratory rabies diagnosis. 
(c)  It shall be the burden of the person killing any animal, as outlined in subsection (b) above, to show the necessity of killing such animal to protect the life of any person or other animal. 
(d)  The carcass of any dead animal exposed to rabies or suspected of having rabies shall, upon demand, be surrendered to the local rabies control authority or an animal control officer. 
(e)  No person shall fail or refuse to surrender an animal for supervised quarantine or humane destruction, as required herein for rabies control, when demand therefor is made by the local rabies control authority or his designee. 
(f)  Any person having possession of or responsibility for any quarantined animal shall immediately notify the local rabies authority or an animal control officer if such animal escapes, or becomes or appears to become sick or dies, and, in the case of the death of the animal while under quarantine, shall immediately surrender the dead animal to the local rabies authority or an animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-174. - Release or disposition of quarantined animal at end of quarantine period. 
(a)  If a veterinarian quarantining an animal or the local rabies control authority determines that a quarantined animal does not show the clinical signs of rabies, the animal shall be released to its owner when the quarantine period ends if: 
(1)  The owner has an unexpired rabies vaccination and license tag for the animal; or 
(2)  The animal is vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at the owner's expense and a vaccination certificate and license tag are issued before release. 
(b)  If a veterinarian determines that a quarantined animal shows the clinical signs of rabies, the veterinarian or local rabies control authority shall humanely destroy the animal. If an animal dies or is destroyed while in quarantine, the veterinarian or local rabies control authority shall remove the head or brain of the animal and submit it to the nearest department laboratory for testing. 
(c)  The owner of an animal that is quarantined under this chapter shall pay to the veterinarian or to the local rabies control authority the reasonable costs of the quarantine and disposition of the animal. The veterinarian or local rabies control authority may bring suit to collect such costs. 
(d)  The veterinarian or local rabies control authority may adopt the animal and retain the proceeds or keep, grant, or destroy an animal if the owner or custodian does not take possession of the animal before the fourth day following the final day of the quarantine period. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code § 826.043.  
Sec. 3-175. - Area rabies quarantine by state. 
(a)  If the state board of health declares an area rabies quarantine, the rules adopted by the state board of health supersede all other applicable ordinances or rules applying to the quarantine area and apply until the state board of health or its designee removes the quarantine by declaration or until the rules expire or are revoked by the state board of health. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if the person violates a rule of the state board of health adopted under V.T.C.A. Texas Health and Safety Code § 826.045 governing an area rabies quarantine. 
(c)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-176. - Limitation on liability. 
A veterinarian performing duties under this chapter is not liable to the owner of an animal for the death of or injury to the animal except in a case of willful misconduct or gross negligence. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-177. - Exemption from quarantine requirement for police service animals. 
(a)  In this section, "handler or rider" and "police service animal" have the meanings assigned by V.T.C.A. Penal Code § 38.151. 
(b)  A police service animal is exempt from the quarantine requirement of this article if the animal bites a person while the animal is under routine veterinary care or while the animal is being used for law enforcement, corrections, prison, or jail security, or investigative purposes. If after biting the person the animal exhibits any abnormal behavior, the law enforcement agency and the animal's handler or rider shall make the animal available within a reasonable time for testing by the animal shelter or a veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Secs. 3-178—3-189. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - DANGEROUS DOGS 
 
Sec. 3-190. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the city by providing for the disposition of dogs determined to be dangerous. 
(b)  The administrative procedures of this article shall apply to any dog required to be restrained in accordance with this article which, while running at large or while restrained in a public place, has bitten or attacked a person or, while running at large or while restrained in a public place, has bitten or attacked another animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-191. - Definitions. 
Words or terms used in this article shall have the following meanings, unless the context shall indicate another or different meaning or intent: 
Additional enclosure requirements means a house, building, structure, or pen which is, in addition to other proper or secure enclosure requirements in this chapter or state law: 
(1)  A house or a building, or in the case of a fence or structure/pen, the fence or structure/pen must be six (6) feet in height. The structure/pen must also have minimum dimensions of five (5) feet by ten (10) feet. The fence or structure/pen must form an enclosure suitable to prevent entry of young children, and must be locked and secured such that an animal cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape of its own volition. 
(2)  The enclosure shall be securely locked at all times. The structure/pen shall have secure sides to prevent the dangerous animal or registered dangerous dog from escaping from the enclosure. 
(3)  The structure/pen shall provide protection from the elements for the animal. The animal control division may require a fence higher than six (6) feet or require a secure top and/or a secure bottom to the structure/pen if the need is demonstrated. 
(4)  A structure such as a house, mobile home, apartment, travel trailer, or other habitation or similar structure is not a secure enclosure when any window is open, or when a screen window or screen door or other penetrable barrier is the only obstacle preventing the animal from exiting the structure, or when any door of another opening used for entry or exit by persons or animals is accessible to the dangerous animal 
Bodily injury means physical pain, illness, or any impairment of physical condition. 
Leash means secured on the owner's property by a leash, or other humane restraint, no longer than four (4) feet in length, held by a person of sufficient strength to restrain the animal, and muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent the animal from biting any person or any other animal. 
Menacing means the showing by a dog of a disposition, determination, or intent to attack or inflict injury or harm to a person or another domestic animal, such as anyone, or a combination, of the following or similar acts: biting, snarling, charging aggressively toward a person or another animal, growling with curled lips, popping of teeth, or barking with raised hackles. 
Register means to fully comply with and maintain all conditions of registration (section 3-194) and applicable orders, including the following: 
(1)  Provide the animal control authority with the name, address and telephone number of the person owning or harboring a dangerous dog; 
(2)  Provide the animal control authority with the name, general description and two (2) color photographs, one (1) depicting a frontal view and one (1) depicting a side view of the dangerous dog; 
(3)  Agree to inspections by animal control officers of the dangerous dog and the premises on which the dangerous dog is kept at any reasonable time to insure compliance with the provisions of this article; and 
(4)  Payment of any cost or fee assessed by the animal control authority related to the registration, seizure, acceptance, impoundment, or destruction of the dog. 
Serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or severe ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment. An offense involving serious bodily injury is a class A misdemeanor with criminal jurisdiction for its enforcement in the Tarrant County Courts. 
Sign(s) means a sign, at least eight (8) inches by twelve (12) inches, of a permanent nature stating "BEWARE OF DANGEROUS DOG" in red lettering on a white background. The lettering shall be no less than two (2) inches in height and made of a reflective material that is visible in low-light situations or at night. In addition, the sign shall include a symbol warning, understandable by small children, of the presence of a dangerous dog. 
Unprovoked or without provocation means the dog was not hit, kicked, or struck by the person or animal with any object or part of the attacked person's or animal's body nor was any part of the dog's body pulled, pinched or squeezed by the person or animal. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-192. - Reporting of incident/dangerous dog determination. 
(a)  If a person reports a dangerous dog incident, the animal control authority shall investigate the incident. The animal control authority may adopt appropriate forms to aid in the enforcement of this section. If, after receiving the sworn statements of any witnesses, the animal control authority determines the dog is a dangerous dog, it shall notify the owner of the determination. 
(b)  Not later than the 15th day after the date the owner is notified that a dog owned by he/she is a dangerous dog, the owner may appeal the determination of the animal control authority to the Everman Municipal Court. An owner may appeal the decision of the Everman Municipal Court in the manner set forth in section 3-200 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-193. - Requirements for dangerous dogs. 
(a)  Not later than the 30th day after the owner learns that he/she is the owner of a dangerous dog, he/she shall: 
(1)  Register the dangerous dog with the animal control authority for the area in which the dog is kept; 
(2)  Restrain the dangerous dog at all times on a leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure as defined in this chapter and that also meets the additional enclosure requirements of this article; 
(3)  Obtain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in an amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to cover damages resulting from an attack by the dangerous dog causing bodily injury to a person and provide proof of the required liability insurance coverage or financial responsibility to the animal control authority for the area in which the dog is kept; 
(4)  Conspicuously display signs, approved by the animal control authority at the property lines located on the front and rear of the property and on the secure enclosure of the dangerous dog; 
(5)  Post written notice to all persons residing within two hundred (200) feet of the owner's house of the presence of the dangerous dog; and 
(6)  The animal control official may require a secure bottom to the structure or pen if the need is demonstrated. 
(b)  The owner of a dangerous dog who does not comply with subsection (a) shall immediately deliver the dog to the animal control authority. 
(c)  If, on application of any person, the municipal court finds, after notice and hearing as provided by section 3-197, that the owner of the dog has failed to comply with subsection (a) or (b) of this section, the court shall order the animal control authority to seize the dog and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure. The animal control authority shall seize the dog or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions. 
(d)  The owner shall pay any cost or fee assessed by the city and or animal shelter. 
(e)  The court shall order the animal control authority to humanely destroy the dog if the owner has not complied with subsection (a) before the 11th day after the date on which the dog is seized or delivered to the animal control authority. The court shall order the authority to return the dog to the owner if the owner complies with subsection (a) before the 11th day after the date on which the dog is seized or delivered to the animal control authority. 
(f)  The court may order the humane destruction of a dog if the owner of the dog has not been located before the 15th day after the seizure and impoundment of the dog. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, a person learns that he/she is the owner of a dangerous dog when: 
(1)  The owner knows of a dangerous dog attack described in the definition of "dangerous dog" in section 3-2 of this chapter; 
(2)  The owner receives notice that the Everman Municipal Court has found that the dog is a dangerous dog; or 
(3)  The owner is informed by the animal control authority that the dog has been determined to be a dangerous dog under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 2(Att. A), 9-12-17)  
Sec. 3-194. - Registration. 
(a)  The animal control authority shall annually register a dangerous dog if the owner: 
(1)  Presents proof of: 
a.  liability insurance or financial responsibility as required in section 3-193(a)(3); 
b.  Current rabies vaccination of the dangerous dog; 
c.  The secure enclosure in which the dangerous dog will be kept; 
(2)  Pays an annual registration fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  The animal control authority shall provide a dangerous dog registration tag to the owner registering a dangerous dog. The owner must place the tag on the dog's collar and commits an offense if the tag and collar are not securely attached to the dog.
