(b)  Should any applicant be aggrieved by the refusal of the chief electrical inspector to grant such reciprocal license, as provided for in this section, such applicant shall have the right to appeal such decision to the city's planning and zoning commission, by the giving of notice to the planning and zoning commission within thirty (30) days of such decision to refuse such license, and upon hearing the planning and zoning commission shall determine whether or not there were reasonable grounds upon which such chief electrical inspector denied such license, and should the planning and zoning commission determine that reasonable grounds for such decision to refuse such license did not exist, the planning and zoning commission shall order such license to issue, otherwise such decision of the chief electrical inspector shall remain final. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 15, Art. 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-164. - Transfer or use by others prohibited. 
No license in effect, issued or renewed under the terms of this division, shall ever be transferred to or used by any other person other than the one to whom the same is or shall be issued. 
(Ord. No 363, § 13, Art. 15, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-165. - Allowing use of name or license by another prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any holder of any license of any grade issued under this division to allow his name or license to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, for the purpose of obtaining a permit for performing work under his license. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 16, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-166. - Employment of unlicensed electricians by license holders prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for a master electrician or a sign electrician to send any person on any job requiring a license in the capacity of an electrician unless such person is the holder of and is in possession of a journeyman electrician's license or a journeyman electrician's temporary working permit, or is accompanied and supervised in his work by a person holding and in possession of a journeyman electrician's license, unless such person sent on such job in such capacity is himself the holder of an unexpired, unrevoked master or sign electrician's license entitling him to perform such work. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 17, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-167. - Journeyman electricians to carry licenses or permits at all times while working. 
Journeyman electricians who are not the holders of unexpired, unrevoked, master or sign electrician's licenses entitling them to perform such work shall carry their journeyman electrician's licenses or journeyman electrician's temporary working permits on their persons at all times while performing electrical work, and they shall produce and present such licenses or permits immediately upon the request of any electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 18, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-168. - Licensees to furnish inspectors with addresses and telephone numbers. 
Each holder of a license of any grade under this division shall furnish the electrical inspector with a written notice of his permanent address, and each holder of a master electrician's license and of a sign electrician's license shall furnish the electrical inspector with a written notice of the address and telephone number of his regularly established place of business. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 19, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-169. - Forfeiture for failure to renew. 
Any holder of any renewable license of any grade who shall fail to pay any renewal fee due for such license within sixty (60) days after the date such fee becomes due shall forfeit such license, and the same shall be and become null and void from and after the expiration of such sixty-day period. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 9, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-170. - Suspension. 
Upon final conviction of any violation of any provision of this article in any court having jurisdiction thereof of any holder of any license issued or renewed under the terms of this division, the city council may suspend the license of such person so convicted for any period up to six (6) months, and during the time of such suspension, such license shall be and become null and void. After the termination of such period of suspension, such license shall again be valid and effective, provided that renewal fees which may have become due thereon, as hereinafter set out, were paid when due. If any licensee is convicted three (3) times for a violation of any provision of this article, the city council may revoke and cancel his license. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 3, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-171. - Expiration. 
Any license issued under the terms of this division shall expire thirty (30) days after the annual renewal fee due thereon becomes due and payable unless such fee is paid before the expiration of such thirty-day period. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 13, Art. 8, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-172—4-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11. 
 
Sec. 4-191. - Permits—Required. 
(a)  Within the corporate limits of the city, no electrical equipment shall be installed within or on any building, structure, or premises publicly or privately owned, nor shall any alteration or addition be made to any such existing equipment without first securing a permit therefor from the chief electrical inspector. 
(b)  A separate permit shall be required for each separate building, store space, or apartment, whether such unit is metered separately or conjunctively, and a service permit shall be taken on all such units whether supplied from a central metering station or directly from an electricity supply agency. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 8, Art. 1, § 9, Art. 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-192. - Same—Application; insurance; issuance. 
Application for the permit required by section 4-191, describing the work to be done, shall be made in writing to the chief electrical inspector by the licensed master electrician or licensed sign electrician installing the work. The applicant shall file a liability insurance policy with the city in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property, two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) personal, with a maximum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per incident, for liabilities incurred by the granting of a work permit and to the benefit of any person damaged by the work performed by the contractor, and for the use and benefit of any person having a cause of action arising out of the contractor's work, done by reason of failure to comply with the building code of the city, by such principal or any of his employees, agents, or subcontractors, except that an owner may make electrical installations, alterations or additions to his own home in which he resides, on first securing a homeowner's permit to do such work himself. Nothing about such homeowner having the right to do such work himself shall affect, or detract from, the obligation and duty of such homeowner to comply with all of the terms and provisions of this article. When required by the chief electrical inspector, the application shall be accompanied by such plans, specifications, and schedules as may be necessary to determine whether the installation as described will be in conformity with the requirements of this article. If it shall be found that the installation as described will conform with all legal requirements and if the licensed master electrician or sign electrician has complied with all provisions of this article, a permit for such installation shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 8, Art. 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-193. - Same—Issuance restricted. 
No permit for constructing, installing, altering, extending, maintaining, repairing, or replacing any electrical wiring, apparatus, or equipment of any voltage in excess of twenty-four (24) volts shall be issued to any person other than a holder of a license of the grade necessary to entitle such holder to lawfully do or supervise the work to be done by virtue of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 8, Art. 4, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-194. - Same—Fees. 
Before any permit is granted for the installation or alteration of electrical equipment, the licensed master electrician or sign electrician making application for such permit shall pay to the electrical inspector's office a fee in such amount as specified in the Uniform Administrative Code adopted under Article II of this chapter, which provides methods of calculation for such fees as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 9, Art. 1, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-195. - Same—Compliance with terms required. 
No deviation may be made from the installation described in the permit issued under this division without the written approval of the chief electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 8, Art. 3, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-196. - Same—Penalty for failure to obtain. 
When work is found to be in progress or completed for which no application for permit has been made or authorization to proceed with the work granted by the chief electrical inspector, an investigation fee of double the amount of the inspection fee shall be added to the inspection fee, the total amount of which shall be paid by the person doing such work, except that work done by licensed journeymen electricians under the supervision of licensed master electricians at night and on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays for which application for permit is made between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. on the first regular working day after which work was done shall be charged with an investigation fee. Payment of such investigation fee shall in no way excuse such person from the penalty set forth in section 1-7 for any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 8, Art. 5, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-197. - Inspections and notices. 
(a)  Upon completion of any installation of electrical equipment, which has been made under a permit, it shall be the duty of the licensed master or sign electrician making the installation to notify the chief electrical inspector, who shall inspect the installation within forty-eight (48) hours, exclusive of Saturday afternoons, Sundays and holidays, of the time such notice is given or as soon thereafter as practicable. 
(b)  Where the chief electrical inspector finds the installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this article, he shall issue to the licensed master or sign electrician making the installation a notice of conformance, which shall be placed on the equipment or premises, authorizing the use of the installation, and shall send written notice of such authorization for connection to the supply of electricity to the agency supplying the electric service. 
(c)  When a certificate of approval is issued authorizing the connection and use of a temporary installation, such certificate shall be issued to expire at a time to be stated herein, and shall be revocable by the chief electrical inspector for good cause. 
(d)  When any electrical equipment is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of the building and/or equipment, the licensed master or sign electrician installing the equipment shall notify the chief electrical inspector, or until forty-eight (48) hours, exclusive of Saturday afternoons, Sundays and holidays, shall have elapsed from the time of such notification, provided that on large installations where the concealment of equipment proceeds continuously, the licensed master or sign electrician installing the electrical equipment shall give the electrical inspector due notice, and inspections shall be made periodically during the progress of the work. 
(e)  If upon inspection the installation is not found to be fully in conformity with the provisions of this article, the chief electrical inspector shall issue a notice of nonconformance and shall notify the licensed master or sign electrician making the installation of the defects which have been found to exist. All defective work shall be corrected and brought in conformity with the provisions of this article before any further electrical work will be permitted within or on the building or premises, and before the licensed master or sign electrician making the installation shall be issued any other permits to perform any other electrical work. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal or place in operation any electrical equipment which has been disapproved or condemned by the chief electrical inspector unless and until the same has been so repaired or altered that it complies with all provisions of this article and has thereafter been approved by the chief electrical inspector. 
(g)  The chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to require any person to uncover any wiring or electrical equipment which has been concealed without the knowledge or permission of the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 10, Arts. 1—7, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-198—4-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 4-221. - Installation of electrical equipment. 
(a)  All installations of electrical equipment made within the corporate limits of the city shall conform to the following specified requirements: 
(1)  All electrical wiring within or on all buildings hereinafter erected and all alterations in and additions to such wiring in or on buildings in existence on September 9, 1986, shall be installed in an approved metal raceway system, except that this provision shall not apply to single-family dwellings and duplex apartment buildings which are not located in fire zones or which may hereafter be designated and defined by the city council. 
(2)  All electrical wiring within or on all commercial buildings hereinafter erected which are used as a combination of living quarters and business, and/or industrial establishments, and alterations and additions to such wiring in or on buildings in existence on September 9, 1986, shall be installed in an approved metal raceway system. 
(3)  All electrical wiring for motors larger than two (2) horsepower within or on private residences and duplex apartments shall be installed in an approved metal raceway system. 
(4)  All electrical service conductors within or on any and all buildings hereinafter erected shall be installed in rigid metal conduit or electrical metallic tubing not smaller than one and one-quarter-inch trade size, which shall extend from the service head to the service entrance switch, or switches, except that this raceway for private single-family residences containing not more than three hundred (300) square feet and not more than two (2) two-wire circuits shall be not smaller than one-inch trade size. 
(5)  All electrical wiring in or on all residences having more than four (4) attached garages hereinafter erected, and all alterations and additions to buildings in existence on September 9, 1986, shall be installed in an approved metal raceway system. 
(6)  All electrical wiring installed on the outside surface of any building or landscaping within the corporate city limits, including private residences, shall be run in an approved and properly grounded metal raceway. This subsection shall not apply to the use of decorative holiday lighting or lighting displays during the period that begins on October 15 and ends on February 1 of each year. All decorative holiday lighting or lighting displays must be removed no later than February 1 of each year. 
(7)  Lead-covered conductors shall be installed in an approved raceway system. 
(8)  Metal raceways shall be cut by saws or metal-removing parting tools of the type which leaves a clean square cut. Pipe cutting tools of the type which spreads or crushes the metal shall not be used. 
(9)  Electrical services in the network zone shall be connected to the underground network system, and if serving more than eight (8) two-wire circuits, or four (4) three-wire circuits, shall be three-phase. 
(10)  The point of entrance of electrical service wires on underground services and the point of landing of electrical service drops on overhead services shall be designated by the electricity supply agency and approved by the chief electrical inspector. All facilities for the installation of meters shall meet the metering requirements of the electricity supply agency. 
(11)  Service entrance conductors within or on all buildings hereinafter erected or within or on all buildings in existence on September 9, 1986, on which the electrical wiring is altered, extended, revised or remodeled, shall be of sufficient size to carry the connected load and in no case shall be smaller than the following: 
a.  Three (3) conductors having a current-carrying capacity of one hundred twenty-five (125) amperes for buildings having one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet of floor area and over, and not more than one hundred (100) amperes connected load. 
b.  Three (3) conductors having a current-carrying capacity of ninety-five (95) amperes for individual occupancy buildings having one thousand two hundred (1,200) or less square feet of floor area and not more than seventy-six (76) amperes connected load. 
c.  Three (3) conductors having a current-carrying capacity of fifty-five (55) amperes for individual occupancy of buildings having six hundred (600) or less square feet of floor area and not more than forty-five (45) amperes connected load and for billboards with not more than forty-five (45) amperes total connected load. 
d.  Two (2) conductors having a current-carrying capacity of fifty-five (55) amperes for buildings having one hundred (100) or less square feet of floor area and not more than two (2) twenty-ampere, two-wire circuits and for billboards with not more than two (2) twenty-ampere, two-wire circuits. 
e.  Two (2) conductors having a current-carrying capacity of forty (40) amperes for temporary services on construction poles. 
(12)  Exceptions to subparagraph (11) are as follows: If an existing structure is damaged by fire or other cause fifty (50) percent or more, or over fifty (50) percent is added to the floor area of the existing building, subparagraph (11) applies. If an existing structure is damaged less than fifty (50) percent, or less than fifty (50) percent is added to the building, the following will apply: 
When the wiring in old structures is altered, extended, revised or remodeled, the load will be figured on three (3) watts per square foot basis, plus a minimum of one (1) sixteen-ampere appliance circuit and separate circuits for each heavy or fixed appliance. See subparagraph (4) of this section. A minimum of one (1) duplex receptacle for every twelve (12) linear feet of each room, not including doors or windows that reach to the floor (picture windows), shall be installed. In new rooms added to old structures, subparagraph (a)(51) of this section shall apply. If the total load is over forty-five (45) amperes, a one and one-quarter-inch riser and three (3) Number 2 wires shall be used, provided the load does not exceed seventy-six (76) amperes; if the load is under forty-five (45) amperes, sixty-ampere wire, three (3) Number 6 wires, and one-inch electrical metallic tubing or conduit shall be used, provided the building is over three hundred (300) feet square and over two (2) circuits; if the building is under three hundred (300) square feet and requires two (2) circuits or less, a two-wire Number 6 service with one-inch electrical metallic tubing or conduit may be used. 
The city council recognizes the fact that the chief electrical inspector may exercise reasonable judgment in the application of this subparagraph. 
(13)  Service drop conductors shall be installed in such a manner that they shall not be within reach from any porch or stair landing, and shall be insulated at the point of connection to the service entrance conductors. 
(14)  The system common ground conductor shall be installed as approved by the chief electrical inspector. 
(15)  Meter bases, switches, and enclosures shall be firmly secured to mounting surfaces with approved type fastening devices independently of and in addition to fastening devices used to secure raceways to the surfaces. 
(16)  All service switches of whatever capacity or potential shall be installed at a location as near the point of entrance of service as may be possible, considering the character of the building and accessibility in case of fire or other reasons for opening the switch and disconnecting the premises from the electricity supply service. 
(17)  Brackets or other means of attachment shall be installed on buildings for service wires, unless such buildings are of wood construction and lend themselves readily to the installation by the electrical supply company of screw-mounting insulators without damage to the outside finish. 
(18)  Service entrance switches which are equipped with meter testing lugs and which are known to the trade as "meter-trim" switches shall be installed sixty-four (64) inches from the top of the switch to the floor. Immediately above and adjacent to this switch shall be installed a wooden meter board twenty (20) inches high and of the width of the switch. 
(19)  All sealed type meter bases shall be installed not less than four (4) feet and not more than six (6) feet, six (6) inches from the center of such bases to the finished grade level of the ground or from the floor. 
(20)  A current transformer metering board not less than twenty-four (24) inches by thirty (30) inches shall be installed at a maximum of seven (7) feet from the top of the board to the floor. 
(21)  Not less than three (3) feet of each conductor shall be left at the service head for connection to the service drop. 
(22)  Service entrance conductors shall not be run at a distance greater than twenty (20) feet within the hollow spaces of frame buildings, unless provided with automatic over-current protection at their outer ends. 
(23)  Service heads shall be installed at a location not more than two (2) feet from the service drops and if possible not less than three (3) feet from any door, window, or other opening in the building. 
(24)  Service entrance switches or any service equipment shall not be installed within a bathroom, toilet, closet, or cabinet, nor within eight (8) feet vertically or five (5) feet horizontally of any plumbing or grounded metal equipment. 
(25)  Service heads shall be installed not less than ten (10) feet, six (6) inches, nor more than twenty-two (22) feet above the ground and so situated that they shall not be within reach from any porch or stair landing, and if practicable shall afford direct unobstructed space for stringing service drops without the necessity of such drops passing over the property of others than the owner of the property being served. 
(26)  Where service heads cannot be installed not less than ten (10) feet, six (6) inches above the ground or platform and service drops cannot be installed at least ten (10) feet above the ground or platform, on account of the structural form of the building, an additional structure shall be erected to afford the necessary height. This structure shall be of sufficient strength to support the attached service drops and shall be of metal protected from corrosion by cadmium, tin, zinc, or equal coating on all surfaces. In no case shall this structure be of inferior strength to two-inch trade size, heavy-wall, rigid steel conduit or three-inch by three-inch by three-inch by one-fourth-inch angle iron. If this structure protrudes through the roof, it shall be of sufficient height to maintain between the bottom service drop and the highest point of the roof over which it passes a clearance of not less than eight (8) feet, except that where the voltage does not exceed three hundred (300) volts between conductors and the roof cannot be readily walked upon, this clearance shall be not less than three (3) feet; or if the structure protrudes through any roof within two (2) feet of the edge of such roof, this clearance shall be not less than one (1) foot. Where the service mast pierces the roof, the roof shall be reinforced by a two-inch by six-inch timber secured underneath and adjacent to the roof structure through the center of which the mast shall pass. 
(27)  Service heads shall be installed at a point above the level of the service drops. 
(28)  Where changes or additions are being made to existing electrical installations, necessitating changes or additions to the service equipment, such service equipment shall be changed to conform to the provisions of this article. 
(29)  Where changes or additions to services or service equipment are being made, all connected wiring and equipment shall be changed to conform to the provisions of this article. 
(30)  Any electricity supply agency, company, firm or corporation operating under a franchise granted by the city shall have the right to install and connect, or disconnect and remove its meters and protective devices without a permit, but it shall not connect any electrical equipment to a source of supply without first having been authorized in writing to do so by the chief electrical inspector. 
(31)  Where meters were originally or may be hereafter installed in inaccessible places in houses or buildings and the electricity supply agency desires to relocate such meters for its own convenience in rendering its service, or for the purpose of standardization of its service in the interest of the public, a licensed master electrician who does such work shall obtain the necessary permits before executing such work. 
(32)  Where meters originally installed in accessible places satisfactory to the electricity supply agency and are rendered inaccessible thereafter by virtue of alterations or new construction by the owner of the premises or his agent, such meters shall be reinstalled in accordance with the provisions of this article at the expense of the owner. 
(33)  Any electricity supply agency, company, firm, or corporation operating under a franchise granted by the city shall supply all three-wire, single-phase services with three-wire, single-phase service drops to premises whereon electricity furnished by such organization is used, and shall, when practicable, furnish the type and size of service needed and requested, except that it shall not be required to furnish three-phase service unless such service is available in the vicinity and unless in addition there is a power demand of at least seven (7) horsepower, at least five (5) horsepower of which is three-phase. 
(34)  Trailer courts shall be wired with weatherproof fittings and equipment, with not more than one (1) trailer to each twenty-ampere circuit, such circuit, to terminate in a heavy-duty, polarized, three-pole receptacle, shall be protected with a fuse disconnect switch. Each individual trailer disconnect switch shall be grounded. 
(35)  Temperature sensitive cut-out switches shall be mounted near the blower in all ventilating and air-conditioning ducts and in the air stream in attic fan installations. The switch shall be so designed that it will open the power circuit to the blower when the actuating air reaches a temperature of one hundred ninety-four (194) degrees Fahrenheit (or ninety (90) degrees Celsius) and shall remain in the open-circuit position until manually reset. 
(36)  Conductors supplying outlets for ranges shall be of sufficient size for the range connected, but in no case shall they be smaller than Number 6 for phase wires and Number 8 for neutrals. 
(37)  Not more than eight (8) current-consuming outlets shall be connected to a fifteen-ampere, general-use branch circuit. 
(38)  Not more than three (3) heavy-duty lamp holders shall be connected to a fifteen-ampere branch lighting circuit. 
(39)  Not more than ten (10) current-consuming outlets shall be connected to a twenty-ampere, general-use branch circuit. 
(40)  Not more than four (4) heavy-duty lamp holders shall be connected to a twenty-ampere lighting circuit. 
(41)  Not more than four (4) current-consuming outlets shall be connected to a twenty-ampere appliance circuit. 
(42)  Bell transformers shall not be installed in attics or underneath structures or buildings with combustible floors, walls, or ceilings. 
(43)  Control transformers for heating or cooling units of other equipment shall not be installed in attics or underneath structures or buildings unless such transformers are enclosed inside the metal enclosure of the unit and protected by the proper size primary fuses with such fuses and associated disconnecting switch or switches in sight of such transformers. 
(44)  Plug fuses and fuse holders shall not be used in ungrounded circuits supplied by delta connected transformers having one (1) phase with a voltage to ground greater than one hundred fifty (150) volts and known to the trade as the "high-leg-to-ground." 
(45)  Plug fuses installed in residential occupancies shall be of the time-delay type. 
(46)  Anesthetizing locations in hospitals and clinics using combustible anesthetic agents shall be wired with equipment which will operate safely in atmospheres containing ethyl ether vapor. Equipment approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. for group C locations and installed in accordance with the provisions of the National Electrical Code and the Recommended Safe Practice for Hospital Operating Rooms as adopted by the National Fire Protection Association will be prima facie evidence that such equipment and installation methods are safe for such locations. 
(47)  All electrical conductors running underneath streets, alleys, easements, and/or sidewalks shall be installed not less than eighteen (18) inches beneath the surface or have equivalent protection. 
(48)  All unused electrical equipment within or on public or private buildings or premises shall be removed. 
(49)  All metal noncurrent-carrying parts and enclosures of electrical equipment shall be grounded if within reach from the ground or from any grounded object. A distance of eight (8) feet vertically and five (5) feet horizontally shall be deemed out of reach. 
(50)  Receptacles within reach of the ground or from grounded objects shall be the grounding type and shall be effectively grounded. Receptacles of more than one hundred fifty (150) volts between conductors or to ground shall be the grounding type and shall be effectively grounded regardless of location. 
(51)  Noncurrent-carrying metal parts of electrical equipment and receptacles of the grounding type which are supplied by nonmetallic wiring systems shall be grounded by means of an equipment grounding conductor connected to a grounding terminal designed for the purpose and run with and within the same enclosure or covering as the current-carrying conductors to the main service equipment and attached to the system grounding electrode at or ahead of the service equipment. Such grounding type receptacles, when supplied by metallic wiring systems, shall be grounded in the manner required for nonmetallic wiring systems unless effectively bonded to and grounded by the metallic raceway systems. 
(52)  The motor disconnecting switch and the motor controller shall both be located within sight of the motor unless such disconnecting switch is capable of being locked in the open position by a padlock and then only when such padlocked switches installed out of sight would result in an installation equally as safe as when installed within sight. Toggle switches in series withholding coil circuit shall not be acceptable in lieu of the above requirements. 
(53)  Connected loads, after demand factors have been applied, shall not exceed eighty (80) percent of the rating of any conductor, switch, circuit breaker, panelboard, or switchboard. 
(54)  The total load connected to a branch circuit shall not exceed eighty (80) percent of the rated current-carrying capacity of the circuit. 
(55)  Electrical wiring shall not be installed inside of buildings until the interior of such buildings have been physically protected from the weather. 
(56)  Approved receptacle outlets shall be installed in sufficient number in walls, floors, and ceilings in every location including residential occupancies, to prevent the number of flexible cords greater in length than six (6) feet for plug-in appliances, fixtures and equipment. In no case shall any wall have less than one (1) receptacle for each twelve (12) linear feet or major fraction thereof measured horizontally along such walls parallel to the floor line after door openings have been deducted, except that such twelve-foot minimum requirement shall not be mandatory for churches, schools, auditoriums, hospitals, storage warehouses, parking garages, office buildings, and other such buildings where other provisions, such as underfloor raceways, have been made, or were it has been clearly established that unsafe substitute wiring will not be installed if such approved receptacles are omitted. On wall areas or work repair benches, behind bars or serving counters, or on which electric signs and similar devices are likely to be placed, not less than one (1) receptacle shall be installed for each six (6) linear feet or major fraction thereof measured horizontally along such walls parallel to the floor or ceiling line. For ceiling areas in lounges, bars, taverns, or other locations where signs, or similar electrical equipment, are likely to be attached, receptacles shall be installed in sufficient number that no point on such ceilings will be at a distance greater than twenty (20) feet from at least one (1) such receptacle. 
(57)  In residential occupancies, at least one (1) approved receptacle outlet shall be installed in each twelve (12) feet of wall space or major fraction thereof, after door openings have been deducted, in each wall other than in hallways and outside unenclosed porches; and at least one (1) fixed lighting fixture or lampholder shall be installed in each kitchen, bathroom, toilet, laundry, pantry, garage, store room, or other room not likely to be lighted with floor lamps. 
(58)  Any electrical appliance rated at six (6) amperes or more shall be supplied by a separate individual circuit. 
(b)  In addition to the requirements set out above, all installations of electrical equipment made within the corporate limits of the city shall be so made that the same will be in safe condition and shall be made in conformity with the provisions of this article and be applicable statutes of the state, and all orders, rules and regulations issued by authority thereof. 
(c)  If equipment and installations meet the requirements set out in paragraph (a) of this section, then conformity with all applicable regulations set forth in the National Electrical Code and in the National Electrical Safety Code shall be prima facie evidence that such installations are in safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 6, Arts. 1—3, 9-9-86; Ord. No. 622, § 1, 3-10-09)  
Sec. 4-222. - Electrical equipment. 
(a)  All electrical equipment installed or used shall be in safe condition and in conformity with the provisions of this article, the applicable statutes of the state and any orders, rules, or regulations issued by authority thereof. 
(b)  Conformity of electrical equipment with applicable standards of Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., shall be prima facie evidence that such equipment is in safe condition. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to equipment owned and used by an electricity supply or communication agency in the generation, transmission, or distribution of electricity or for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 7, Art. 3, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-223—4-245. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - CONTRACTORS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11. 
 
Sec. 4-296. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of mechanical construction, alteration, additions or repairs, without first presenting to the city a license issued by the state for the appropriate work being performed, and filing with the city proof of liability insurance as required. 
(b)  A class A state license is required if any single cooling source unit develops more than three hundred thousand (300,000) BTU's per hour (twenty-five (25) tons) of cooling capacity or if any single heating unit develops more than one and one-half (1.5) million BTU's per hour heating capacity. 
(c)  A class B state license is required if any single cooling source unit develops more than three hundred thousand (300,000) BTU's per hour (twenty-five (25) tons) or if any single heating source produces less than one and one-half (1.5) million BTU's per hour heating capacity. A combination of smaller units totaling more than twenty-five (25) tons of cooling or more than one and one-half (1.5) million BTU's of heating capacity shall not required a class A license. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 1, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-297. - Work permits required. 
Any person engaged in the installation, alteration or addition, to a mechanical system shall first obtain a permit from the city and pay the appropriate fees. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-298. - Registration permit. 
Each person applying for an air-conditioning permit shall obtain a registration permit at a cost of one hundred dollars ($100.00) renewable January first of each year at a cost of fifty dollars ($50.00). Any request for renewal after February first shall be processed as a first time request and charged accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 3, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-299. - Display of license number and class of license on vehicle required. 
Each contractor shall display the license number and class of license in letters not less than two (2) inches high on both sides of all vehicles, along with the company name. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 4, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-300. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  Each class A license holder shall furnish the city with proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage, two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) personal injury damage, for a combined amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per occurrence. 
(b)  Each class B license holder shall furnish the city with proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury, property damage in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) aggregate. 
(Ord. No. 365, §§ 5, 6, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-301. - Homeowner's exemption. 
Nothing contained in this division shall prohibit any bona fide homeowner from personally performing the work described in this division, and such bona fide homeowner shall not be required to file proof of liability insurance if the work is totally and completely performed only by the bona fide homeowner, provided such homeowner first obtains a permit, provided that such homeowner installs such system in accordance with all codes of the city, and providing all work under this division shall be at the legal residence of such homeowner. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 7, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-302—4-320. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PLUMBING REGULATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-321. - Plumbing code adopted.

The 2018 International Plumbing Code is fully incorporated by reference as though copied into this article in its entirety. The material contained in the 2018 International Plumbing Code shall not be included in the formal municipal codification of ordinance but shall be maintained as a public record in the office of the city secretary and will be available for public inspection and copying during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 362, § 2, 9-9-86; Ord. No. 475, § 5, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 518, § 5, 1-8-02; Ord. No. 578, § 1, 2-14-06; Ord. No. 610, § 1, 3-11-08; Ord. No. 656, § 1, 5-8-12; Ord. No. 704, § 2, 1-10-17; Ord. No. 748, § 1, 9-10-19) 
Cross reference— Administrative code, § 4-26 et seq.; building code, § 4-51 et seq.; dangerous buildings code, § 4-76 et seq.; electrical code, § 4-103; residential code, § 4-246 et seq.; mechanical code, § 4-271 et seq.; sign code, § 4-371 et seq.; solar energy code, § 4-391 et seq.; swimming pool code, § 4-411 et seq.  
Sec. 4-322. - Building code amendments. 
The 2018 edition of the International Plumbing Code, as adopted herein, is hereby amended in accordance with the recommendations of the North Central Texas Council of Governments and as detailed on Exhibit "A" attached hereto and incorporated by reference. The material contained in Exhibit "A" to this ordinance, although adopted and fully incorporated by reference, shall not be included in the formal codification of the ordinances. The material shall instead be maintained as a public record in the office of the city secretary and made available for public inspection and copying during regular business hours. It may be further amended from time to time by individual ordinances with such amendments to be maintained as public records in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 362, § 4(b), 9-9-86; Ord. No. 475, § 6, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 518, § 6, 1-8-02; Ord. No. 578, § 2, 2-14-06; Ord. No. 610, § 2, 3-11-08; Ord. No. 656, § 2, 5-8-12; Ord. No. 704, § 2, 1-10-17; Ord. No. 748, § 1, 9-10-19)  
Sec. 4-323. - Cross-connection control program. 
(a)  General. No water service connection shall be made to any establishment where a potential or actual contamination hazard exists unless the water supply is protected in accordance with the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems (TNRCC Rules) and this section. The City of Everman shall discontinue water service if a required backflow prevention assembly is not installed, maintained and tested in accordance with the TNRCC Rules and this section. 
(b)  Backflow prevention assembly installation, testing and maintenance. 
(1)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested upon installation by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester and certified to be operating within specifications. Backflow prevention assemblies which are installed to provide protection against health hazards must also be tested and certified to be operating within specifications at least annually by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester. 
(2)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed and tested in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, the American Water Works Association's Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control (Manual M14) or The University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control. 
(3)  Assemblies shall be repaired, overhauled, or replaced at the expense of the customer whenever said assemblies are found to be defective. Original forms of such test, repairs, and overhaul shall be kept and submitted to the city within five (5) working days of the test, repair or overhaul of each backflow prevention assembly. 
(4)  No backflow prevention assembly or device shall be removed from use, relocated, or other assembly or device substituted without the approval of the city. Whenever the existing assembly or device is moved from the present location or can not be repaired, the backflow assembly or device shall be replaced with a backflow prevention assembly or device that complies with this section, The American Water Works Association's Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control (Manual M14), current addition, University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control, current addition, or the current plumbing code of the city, whichever is more stringent. 
(5)  Test gauges used for backflow prevention assembly testing shall be calibrated at least annually in accordance with The American Water Works Association's Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control (Manual M14), current addition, or The University of Southern California's Manual of Cross-Connection Control, current addition. The original calibration form must be submitted to the city within five (5) working days after calibration. 
(6)  A recognized backflow prevention assembly tester must hold a current endorsement from the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (Commission). 
(c)  Customer service inspections. 
(1)  A customer service inspection shall be completed prior to providing continuous water service to all new construction, on any existing service when the city has reason to believe that cross-connections or other contaminant hazards exist, or after any material improvement, correction, or addition to the private water distribution facilities. 
(2)  Only individuals with the following credentials shall be recognized as capable of conducting a customer service inspection: 
a.  Plumbing inspectors and water supply protection specialists that have been licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners. 
b.  Certified waterworks operators, and members of other water related professional groups who have completed a training course, passed an examination administered by the commission or its designated agent, and hold a current endorsement issued by the commission. 
(3)  The customer service inspection must certify that: 
a.  No direct connection between the public drinking water supply and a potential source of contamination is permitted. Potential sources of contamination shall be isolated from the public water system by a properly installed air gap or an appropriate backflow prevention assembly. 
b.  No cross-connection between the public water supply and a private water source exists. Where an actual properly installed air gap is not maintained between the public water supply and a private water supply, an approved reduced pressure-zone backflow prevention assembly is properly installed and a service agreement exists for annual inspection and testing by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester. 
c.  No connection exists which allows water to be returned to the public drinking water supply is permitted. 
d.  No pipe or pipe fitting which contains more than eight (8) percent lead may be used for the installation or repair of plumbing at any connection that provides water for human use. 
e.  No solder of flux which contains more than 0.2 percent lead can be used for the installation or repair of plumbing at any connection that provides water for human use. A minimum of one lead test shall be performed for each inspection. 
(d)  Enforcement. The city public works director shall be responsible for the enforcement of this section. Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000). Each day that one or more of the provisions in this section is violated shall constitute a separate offense. If a person is convicted of three (3) or more distinct violations of this section, the city public works director shall, upon due notice to the customer, be authorized to discontinue water service to the premises where such violations occur. Services discontinued under such circumstances shall be restored only upon payment of the reasonable cost of reconnection and any other costs incurred by the city in discontinuing service. In addition suitable assurances must be given to the city public works director that the same action shall not be repeated while the section is in effect. Compliance with this section may also be sought through injunctive relief in state district court. 
(Ord. No. 514, §§ 1, 2, 9-4-01)  
Secs. 4-324—4-345. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11. 
 
Sec. 4-346. - Licenses required. 
It shall be unlawful to install, construct, maintain, repair, alter, or modify any piping or fixtures used for conducting of water, gas or sewage within the city, except as follows: 
(1)  A master plumber's license issued by the state is required for obtaining a permit and contracting for plumbing installation, modification or repair. 
(2)  A master or journeyman plumber's license issued by the state is required for actual work on the plumbing. A journeyman shall be under the supervision of a master plumber. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 1, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-347. - Work permits required. 
Before a person shall repair, construct, install, alter, or modify any plumbing within the city, he shall first obtain a permit. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-348. - Registration permits required. 
Each person applying for a plumbing permit shall obtain a registration permit from the city at a cost of one hundred dollars ($100.00), renewable thereafter on January 1 of each year at a cost of fifty dollars ($50.00). Any request for renewal after February 1 shall be processed as a first-time request and charged accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 3, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-349. - Insurance requirements. 
Each master plumber shall furnish the city with proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) aggregate. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 5, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-350. - Display of license number and class of license on vehicles required. 
Each contractor shall display the license number and class of license along with the company name on both sides of all vehicles in letters not less than two and one-half (2½) inches high. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 4, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-351. - Persons exempted from license, registration and insurance requirements. 
Exempted from the license, registration and insurance requirements of this division are: 
(1)  Any person who performs plumbing work in a building owned solely by him and is his home residence. 
(2)  Any person as specified in Part 1, section 20.5 of the 1985 Uniform Plumbing Code. 
(3)  Any person or company engaged in the installation and repair of service mains and appurtenances. 
(4)  Any person working for an appliance company and installing an appliance to existing piping. 
(5)  Any person who performs maintenance work if the person is regularly employed as a maintenance man and if the work is performed in connection with the business in which the person is employed and does not engage in the occupation of plumbing contracting for the general public and no extension, alteration, or modification to the plumbing system occurs. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 6, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-352—4-370. - Reserved.

Sec. 4-411. - Swimming pool and spa code adopted. 
The 2018 edition of the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code is hereby adopted as the official swimming pool and spa code of the City of Everman Texas. The 2018 International Swimming Pool and Spa Code is fully incorporated by reference as though copied into this article in its entirety. The material contained in the 2018 International Swimming Pool and Spa Code shall not be included in the formal municipal codification of ordinance but shall be maintained as a public record in the office of the city secretary and will be available for public inspection and copying during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 362, § 2, 9-9-86; Ord. No. 601, § 1, 3-11-08; Ord. No. 697, § 2, 1-10-17; Ord. No. 745, § 1, 9-10-19)  
Sec. 4-412. - Swimming pool and spa code amendments. 
The 2018 edition of the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code, as adopted herein, is hereby amended in accordance with the recommendations of the North Central Texas Council of Governments and as detailed on Exhibit "A" attached hereto and incorporated by reference. The material contained in Exhibit "A" to this ordinance, although adopted and fully incorporated by reference, shall not be included in the formal codification of the ordinances. The material shall instead be maintained as a public record in the office of the city secretary and made available for public inspection and copying during regular business hours. It may be further amended from time to time by individual ordinances with such amendments to be maintained as public records in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 697, § 2, 1-10-17; Ord. No. 745, § 1, 9-10-19)  
Secs. 4-413—4-430. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING BUILDINGS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11. 
 
Sec. 4-431. - Permit—Required; fees. 
No person shall hereafter move any structure or building, excluding portable buildings, within or through the limits of the city, where the same shall be moved in, through or upon the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds, without first obtaining a permit from the city. Any structure or building, excluding portable buildings, moved into the city shall require the owner or agent to first obtain a permit, and such permit cost shall be based upon new construction costs. Permits for moving a structure or building, excluding portable buildings, with a destination other than the city shall be charged one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first day and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional day that the building is in or upon the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 1, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-432. - Same—Plot plan to accompany application. 
Before any building or structure moving permit may be issued for any building or structure with the ultimate destination and permanent location within the city, a plot plan shall be submitted with the application for permit, showing the shape and dimensions of the plot to be occupied by the structure, location of the structure on the lot and sufficient information to show that yard requirements, square footage requirements of the building, and all other subdivision, building and zoning requirements of the city, are to be complied with the same as for a built-on-the-site structure. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 2, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-433. - Same—Insurance prerequisite to issuance. 
Before a permit required by t his article is granted, the person or corporation shall provide proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) personal injury with an aggregate amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 367, § 4, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-434. - Same—Performance bond prerequisite to issuance; allowable time limit. 
Before a permit required by this article is granted, the person applying for a moving permit for a building or structure with a destination within the city shall give a performance bond in an amount as determined by the building official, to complete all work on the building or structure and bring all items to current city building codes. The bond shall be for a term of one (1) year. Further, the maximum time limit allowed within which to bring all items up to code standards shall be one hundred twenty (120) days. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 5, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-345. - Same—Conditions of route. 
A permit issued under this article by the city to a house, building or structure mover shall state specifically all conditions of the permit and designated route as determined by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 7, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-436. - Same—Revocation. 
The city shall revoke a permit if determination is made that the building or structure is being moved in a careless or reckless manner. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 10, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-437. - Structure size to be compatible with neighborhood. 
The moved-in structure, at the time of occupancy, must be of equal or greater size, quality, value and appearance to other structures located within two hundred (200) feet of the lot on which it is to be located, and must be located on a platted lot in a subdivision approved by the planning and zoning board, and be of record in the office of the county clerk. The accomplishment of these ends must be reflected by the submitted plans before a permit will be issued. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 3, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-438. - Utility company notification. 
Any person obtaining a moving permit under this article shall be responsible for coordinating the moving of such building or structure with all utility companies. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 6, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-439. - To be continuous. 
The moving of a building or structure shall be continuous as determined by the chief of police, with regard to the least amount of obstruction to traffic. All buildings or structures which are moved at night shall be sufficiently lighted so as not to be a hazard to the traveling public. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 8, 9-9-86)  
Sec. 4-440. - Reporting upon reaching destination. 
Any person receiving a moving permit under this article shall report within one (1) day after the building or structure reaches its destination, at which time the city shall inspect the route to determine if damage to city property has occurred. Any such damage shall be repaired and charged to such person's insurance carrier. 
(Ord. No. 367, § 9, 9-9-86)  
Secs. 4-441—4-449. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - BUILDING BOARD OF APPEALS 
 
Sec. 4-450. - Building board of appeals created. 
A building board of appeals, referred to in this article as "the board," is hereby created to accomplish purposes and perform functions set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Sec. 4-451. - Appointment and terms. 
The board shall be composed of five (5) members to be appointed by the city council. In addition, the city council shall appoint two (2) alternate members who shall serve in the absence of one or more regular members. Alternate members must meet the same qualifications as regular board members. An alternate member has voting privileges only when sitting in for an absent member. Regular members shall be appointed to places numbered 1 through 5 and alternate members shall be appointed to places numbered 6 and 7. Upon initial appointment pursuant to this article, members in the odd numbered places shall be appointed to serve terms expiring in the year 1999 and members appointed to the even numbered places shall serve terms expiring in the year 2000. Thereafter, the terms of office of the members shall be two (2) years beginning on February 1 of the year of appointment. The terms of the odd numbered places shall expire in the odd numbered years, and the terms of the even numbered places shall expire in the even numbered years. Board members may be appointed to succeed themselves. Vacancies shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired term. Newly appointed members shall be installed at the first regular board meeting after their appointment. The building official shall be an ex officio member of and shall act as secretary to the board, but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. All members of the board shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Sec. 4-452. - Qualifications of members. 
It is the intent of the city council that the board members shall, by reason of diversity of their individual areas of expertise, constitute a board which is broadly representative of various fields of building construction and building standards. In making appointments to the board, the city council if possible will give consideration to persons who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to building construction, mechanical design, plumbing systems or electrical systems, or who have practical experience in matters relating to building construction or value such as a mortgage banker or licensed real estate agent. Members, except for the building official, may not be employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Sec. 4-453. - Organization. 
The board shall hold an organizational meeting in October of each year and shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman from among its members. The board shall meet when required to carry out the duties established by this article. The board shall adopt its own rules and procedures and shall keep a record of its proceedings consistent with the provisions of this article and the requirements of law. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating that fact, and shall keep records of its decisions and other official actions, all which shall be filed in the office of the city secretary and kept as public records. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Sec. 4-454. - Duties and powers. 
(a)  The board is hereby charged with the duty and invested with the authority to: 
(1)  Inspect property and premises at reasonable hours where required in the discharge of its responsibilities under the laws of the state and the city; 
(2)  Hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of the technical provisions of the following codes adopted by the city: 
a.  The Uniform Building Code; 
b.  The Uniform Plumbing Code; 
c.  The Uniform Mechanical Code; 
d.  The National Electrical Code; 
e.  The Uniform Administrative Code; and 
f.  The Uniform Housing Code. 
(3)  Enforce the provisions of Ordinance No. 468, as codified in Article IV of Chapter 4 of the Everman Code, the Substandard Building Ordinance, and carry out the functions established by that ordinance to abate substandard and dangerous buildings. 
(b)  The board shall have no authority relative to interpretation of the administrative provisions of the codes listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section or the ordinance referenced in subsection (a)(3) of this section nor may the board waive requirements of any of the codes listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section or the ordinance referenced in subsection (a)(2) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Sec. 4-455. - Meetings and quorums. 
A quorum for the conduct of business shall consist of four members of the board. Each member is entitled to one vote and action of the board shall require a majority of those members present. The members of the board shall regularly attend meetings of the board and shall serve without compensation, except for reimbursement of authorized expenses attendant to the performance of their duties. The members shall comply with all time limits and public notice requirements and all meetings of the board shall be held in compliance with the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 468, § 1, 1-29-98)  
Secs. 4-456—4-464. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - FENCING AND SCREENING 
 
Sec. 4-465. - Purpose. 
The requirements set forth in this article are intended to promote safety; protect the character and stability of residential, agricultural, commercial and industrial areas, conserve the value of land, buildings and neighborhoods, and enhance the aesthetic and visual image of the city. The construction, modification, and maintenance of fencing and screening devices shall comply with the requirements of this article. The city council may approve deviations from these requirements if it finds that adherence to the requirements of this article will be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-466. - Definitions. 
Building code: The Uniform Building Code as adopted and amended by the city council. 
Fence: Any construction greater than thirty (30) inches in height and of any material, the purpose of which is to provide protection from intrusion (both physical and visual), to prevent escape, mark a boundary, or provide decoration. A wall shall be considered a fence. Dikes and restraining walls for the purpose of diverting water and retaining soil are not classified as a fence. 
Multi-unit rental complex: Two (2) or more dwelling units in one or more buildings that are under common ownership managed by the same owner, managing agent, or management company, and located on the same lot or tract of land or adjacent lots or tracts of land. The term includes a condominium project but does not include: 
(a)  A facility primarily renting rooms to overnight guests; or 
(b)  A single-family home or adjacent homes that are not part of a condominium project. 
Owner: A person who owns, leases or manages or has a legal or equitable interest in a parcel or tract of land. 
Person: A person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity of any kind. 
Pool: A permanent swimming pool, permanent wading or reflection pool, hot tub or spa over eighteen (18) inches deep, located at ground level, above ground level, below ground or indoors. 
Screening device: Any of the following: 
(a)  A solid fence of metal, brick, masonry, or concrete, the vertical surface of which shall be without gaps, except openings for access; 
(b)  A dense screening shrub or plantings providing a visual barrier, and maintained and trimmed in a healthy growing condition; or 
(c)  Landscaped earth berms when approved and appropriate in scale, and used as a screening device in lieu of a fence, wall, hedge or other dense planting material. 
Visual barrier: Any fence, wall, hedge or shrubbery higher than thirty (30) inches above ground level measured at the property line, except single trees with single trunks. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-467. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for a person to erect or cause to be erected a fence or any part thereof without obtaining a permit from the city. Any existing fence may be repaired or modified without obtaining a permit. Any existing fence may be replaced by a fence in the same location without a permit from the city if the replacement fence is completed within six (6) months from the date of removal of the existing fence, provided that no height will be added to the replacement fence. Any repair, modification or replacement performed without a permit shall be in accordance with all other requirements of the ordinances and regulations of the City of Everman. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-468. - Application for permit. 
A person shall apply for a permit at City Hall. The application shall contain the following information: 
(a)  The name, address and phone number of the applicant and the contractor who will perform the work, if different from the applicant; 
(b)  The name and address of the owner of the property, and a description of the property, by legal description or street address; 
(c)  A description of the fencing materials; 
(d)  A copy of the plans, specifications, and diagrams for the construction of the fence unless this requirement is waived by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-469. - Permit fee. 
A person shall pay a fee, as established by the city council by ordinance, resolution, or minute order, at the time the person submits an application for permit. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-470. - Duration of permit. 
(a)  The building official or his designee shall review the application and issue a permit to the applicant, if the building official or his designee finds that the work described in the permit application conforms to the requirements of this article and the building code, and if the application fee has been paid. 
(b)  The permit shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the work authorized by the permit is not commenced within sixty (60) days from the date of the permit, or the work authorized by the permit is suspended for a period of sixty (60) days or more. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-471. - Denial of permit. 
The building official or his designee shall deny a permit if: 
(a)  The applicant fails to submit all information as required by this article; 
(b)  The application reveals that the proposed work does not comply with this Code; or 
(c)  The application reveals that the proposed work will be on the property line and is not approved by all adjacent property owners. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-472. - Appeal of denial of permit. 
A person may appeal the denial of a permit in accordance with the provisions of the building code. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-473. - Fence required—Swimming pool. 
Any person who owns or controls property upon which a swimming pool is located shall enclose the pool yard with a fence in accordance with the provisions of the building code and said person shall maintain such fence to prevent outside intrusion. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-474. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 553, § 1, adopted September 14, 2004, repealed § 4-474 which pertained to fencing of dumpsters and material which had derived from Ord. No. 506, § 1.  
Sec. 4-475. - Fence or screening required—Incompatible uses. 
(a)  A fence or screening device must be erected, placed and/or grown along the common boundary line of incompatible zoning districts before use is made of the property or before a building permit may be issued for construction on property which is adjacent to property that is zoned for a more restrictive use as defined in the city's Zoning Ordinance Number 433. The approved fence or screening device shall be of sufficient height to provide a visual screen, and in no event less than six (6) feet in height. 
(b)  Nonresidential uses in a residential district (as defined by the zoning ordinance) shall be suitably screened from view of any adjacent residential lot or dwelling use along the side and rear property lines of such nonresidential use. Said screening requirements shall not be mandatory for public schools, parks or churches, except where a parking lot or active outdoor intensive use area (such as a playground) is adjacent to a residential lot or dwelling. Parking lot screening need not be more than three and one-half (3½) feet in height. 
(c)  Where a multi-unit rental complex abuts a one- or two-family residence or residential area, the side and rear property lines of said multi-unit rental complex shall be suitably screened from view of any adjacent dissimilar residential dwelling or lot. 
(d)  Off-street loading areas shall be adequately screened from view of any residential dwelling lot or of any other adjacent residential land use, or of any adjacent public or semi-public land use. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-476. - Responsibility for fence. 
Every owner, tenant and agent, of any property upon where a fence or screening device is maintained, shall be jointly and severally responsible for installing and maintaining the fence or screening device. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-477. - Fence maintenance. 
(a)  Fences and screening devices shall be maintained in a good state of repair and free of vegetation in accordance with the city codes and ordinances. 
(b)  Screening devices composed of shrubs or plantings shall be maintained in a healthy, neat, live, growing condition. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-478. - Fence material. 
(a)  A person shall construct a fence using the following materials: wood, wrought iron, exposed aggregate tilt wall, fired masonry, approved wood rail construction or other material approved by the building official or his designee, including large screening shrubs. 
(b)  Wood fences may have metal framing. 
(c)  A person erecting a fence shall ensure that the smooth side faces adjoining streets and all posts and rails face the interior of the lot, unless otherwise approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-479. - Electric fences. 
A person may construct or maintain an electric fence or fence charging devices only if the fence or device is: 
(a)  UL approved; 
(b)  Used in conjunction with agricultural activities for the purpose of containing livestock, protecting water supplies, or for the security of crops grown on the property; and 
(c)  Plainly labeled or marked. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-480. - Security fences. 
(a)  A person may erect and maintain a barbed wire fence for: 
(1)  Agricultural or related activities; or 
(2)  Security purposes in nonresidential zoning districts if the barbed wire is mounted on the top of a fence at least six (6) feet in height. 
(b)  All other barbed wire fences are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-481. - Razor wire fences. 
A person may not use concertina wire or razor wire to construct a fence unless such is authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-482. - Placement of fence or screening device. 
(a)  A person shall not construct or maintain a fence or screening device in such a manner as would endanger the health or safety of the general public. 
(b)  No fence or screening device comprised of brick, masonry, concrete or solid metal shall be erected or placed which would interfere with the installation or maintenance of any public utility line, service, or drainage way, within the easements reserved therefore. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-483. - Front yard fence. 
A person shall not construct a fence exceeding thirty (30) inches in height which extends beyond the front building line of any permitted building in any district designated residential by the zoning ordinance, except that a person may construct a decorative fence, agricultural or security fence that is no more that twenty-five (25) percent solid above thirty (30) inches. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-484. - Side yard fence. 
A person shall not construct or maintain: 
(a)  A fence or screening device exceeding thirty (30) inches in height less than five feet from any side or rear property line that is adjacent to a public right-of-way except for a decorative fence, agricultural or security fence that is no more that twenty-five (25) percent solid above thirty (30) inches; or 
(b)  A fence over thirty (30) inches in height closer than fifteen (15) feet from the front corner property pin of an adjoining lot. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-485. - Visibility. 
(a)  A person shall not construct or maintain a fence, screening device, or other visual barrier so that it obstructs the vision of a motor vehicle driver approaching any street, alley or drive intersection. 
(b)  A person shall construct and maintain a fence, screening device, or other visual barrier in such a manner that a person, from all street intersections, has a clear field of vision across the corner lots for a distance of twenty-five (25) feet back from the property corner along both streets. 
(c)  In the event of a conflict between a provision establishing a minimum fence height and the provisions of this section, a person shall construct the fence so as to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-486. - Height. 
A person shall not construct a fence in a residential district, as defined by the zoning ordinance, which exceeds eight (8) feet in height above ground level at the fence line. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-487. - Public property. 
A person shall not construct a fence, guy wire, brace or any post in such a manner that it protrudes over property that the city or the general public has dominion and control over, owns or has an easement over, under or through except upon utility easements, which are permitted to be fenced. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-488. - Perimeter fencing. 
Subdivision perimeter fencing shall conform to the requirements and provisions for screening and fencing contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)  
Sec. 4-489. - Requirements cumulative. 
A person who erects or maintains a fence shall comply with the applicable provisions of this Code, the building code and the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 506, § 1, 2-13-01)
