The term garage sale includes the terms yard sale, estate sale, occasional sale, and similar terms. 
(Ord. No. 623, § 1, 3-10-09) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3.  
Sec. 11-192. - Regulations. 
(1)  Permit required. A permit shall be required to hold or have a garage sale. The permit may be issued to the owner or tenant of the residence, or to the owner of the nonresidential property. The sign issued by the city shall serve as the permit for the sale. The permit number shall be listed on the sign. The permit for sales on a nonresidential property shall be in addition to any special event sales or temporary outdoor sales allowed by the zoning regulations. 
(2)  Number and duration of sales. The number of garage sales on a property shall not exceed four (4) during any calendar year period from January 1 to December 31. The duration of each sale shall not exceed three (3) consecutive calendar days, except that, if the sale is an estate sale, then the property may be displayed, offered for sale or sold for a continuous period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive calendar days, but under the following terms and conditions: 
(a)  No personal property shall be displayed, offered for sale or sold within an open garage or in a front yard. 
(b)  All displays shall be within the confines of the house. 
(3)  Conditions of sale. Tangible personal property shall be sold only on the premises of the owner or tenant of the residential property where the sale is conducted, or on the premises of the owner of the nonresidential property where the sale is conducted. The owner or tenant must be the legal owner of such tangible personal property at the time of such sale. The items for sale shall be confined to the garage, porch, patio or yard on the premises of the residence, and to the parking lot or sidewalk on the premises of a nonresidential property. No merchandise acquired solely for the purpose of resale, shall be sold at a garage sale. 
(4)  Sales affected by rain or inclement weather. If a property owner or tenant has purchased a garage sale permit, and the majority of the scheduled dates for the sale are affected by rain or other inclement weather, as determined by city staff, a rain-out permit may be issued at no cost provided the property owner or tenant returns the sign originally issued as the permit. The new permit must be issued within thirty (30) days of the date of the original permit. If the permit was issued for two (2) or three (3) days and the rain or inclement weather affects only one (1) day during the permit period, a rain-out permit shall not be issued. 
(5)  Multiple garage sales. In the event of multiple garage sales in one (1 subdivision, each property participating in the event will be required to obtain a permit. 
(6)  Permit fee. The permit fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), fifteen dollars ($15.00) of which shall be refunded when all of the signs are returned as required by subsection 11-193(5). 
(Ord. No. 623, § 1, 3-10-09)  
Sec. 11-193. - Signs. 
(1)  On-premises signs. Three (3) signs shall be issued by the city with the permit. The sign shall be posted on the property conducting the sale in a location visible from the street, as it serves as the permit for the sale. No other garage sale signs shall be permitted. 
(2)  Off-premises signs. Up to two (2) off-premises signs may be placed on private property, subject to permission of the property owner where the sign is to be located. 
(3)  Sign locations. 
(a)  Signs shall not be placed on utility poles, street sign poles, or other fixed objects in the city or state rights-of-way. 
(b)  Signs shall not be placed within a street median or a visibility triangle. 
(4)  Removal of signs. Signs shall not be posted more than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the beginning of the sale. The sign advertising a garage sale shall be removed by the permittee not later than twenty-four (24) hours following the expiration of the permit. 
(5)  Return of sign. The sign must be returned to City Hall within ten (10) days after the expiration of the permit, at which time the refund in subsection 11-192(6) shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 623, § 1, 3-10-09)  
Sec. 11-194. - Right to deny permit. 
If any person is cited for violation of this article two (2) or more times during any twelve-month period, the City of Everman may refuse to issue that individual a permit to hold a garage sale anytime during the subsequent twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 623, § 1, 3-10-09)  
Secs. 11-195—11-215. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PEDDLERS OR SOLICITORS 
 
Sec. 11-216. - Policy of city declared. 
In order to promote and protect the general health, safety and welfare of persons residing in the city, and to secure such persons in their right to privacy and prevention from annoyances, it is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that no person may go in or upon private residences in the city to peddle or sell products or services, or to solicit the sale of products or services, for the private profit of the person doing same, when not requested or invited to do so by the occupants of such residences. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1)  
Sec. 11-217. - Not to go upon private residences without invitation. 
No person may go in or upon a private residence in the city for the purpose of peddling or selling products or services, or to solicit the sale of products or services, for the private profit of the person doing same, when not requested or invited to do so by the occupants of such private residence. 
(Code 1977, § 4-2)  
Sec. 11-218. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the terms of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 4-3)  
Secs. 11-219—11-249. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - USE OF CITY RIGHT-OF-WAY FOR SOLICITATION OR SALES 
 
Sec. 11-250. - Offense. 
It shall be an offense to go upon, stand, or otherwise use the city right-of-way, including streets and highways, to solicit, raise, or ask for donations or contributions, or to sell any goods, product, or service. 
(Ord. No. 474, § 1, 8-11-98)  
Sec. 11-251. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Written permission from city council. It shall not constitute an offense under section 11-250 if a group has written permission from the city council. 
(b)  Application. Any group desiring to obtain written permission from the city council to use the city right-of-way shall file a written application with the city secretary at least three (3) days before a regularly scheduled city council meeting and must have a representative present at the city council meeting. The application must state the date, place, time and purpose for which the group desires to use the city right-of-way, and must list every person that will be participating with the group and the age of each person. 
(c)  Factors in determining whether to grant permission. In determining whether to grant permission to a group, the city council must consider at least the following factors: 
(1)  The age of the participants; 
(2)  The obstruction or interference that the use of the city right-of-way will cause to the flow of traffic; 
(3)  The location at which the group desires to use the city right-of-way; 
(4)  The day and time at which the group desires to use the city right-of-way; 
(5)  The number of people or groups that will be using the city right-of-way at a particular location; and 
(6)  The purpose for which the group desires to use the city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 474, § 1, 8-11-98)  
Secs. 11-252—11-274. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 11-275. - Definitions. 
Alarm business means the business of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, installing, or monitoring an alarm system at an alarm site. 
Alarm site means the specific property or area of the premises on or within which an alarm system is installed or placed. 
(a)  If an alarm system is installed by an individual tenant in an apartment complex, duplex, townhome, mini-storage warehouse, or other similar premises, the tenant shall obtain a permit before operating or causing the operation of the alarm system. The tenant must provide the name of a representative of the complex who can grant access to the apartment or other type of unit. 
(b)  If the owner or property manager of an apartment complex, duplex, townhome, mini-storage warehouse, or other similar premises provides alarm systems in each apartment or other type of unit as an amenity, the owner or property manager shall obtain a permit before operating or causing the operation of the alarm system. 
Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device that is used to protect buildings or premises from criminal acts, unauthorized entries, or fire damage by transmitting a signal intended to summon police or fire services of a municipality or by warning persons of a crime, unauthorized entry or fire through the emission of a sound or the transmission of a signal or message. Alarm system does not include: 
(a)  An alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is used for a habitation at a permanent site; or 
(b)  An alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises. 
False alarm means an alarm signal received by the police chief or his representative for which a response is made within thirty (30) minutes and which, from an inspection of the interior or exterior of the premises, is determined not to involve a criminal offense, attempted criminal offense, fire or other emergency. 
Permit holder means the person designated in an alarm permit application who is responsible for responding to alarms, giving access to the site, and proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of the fees. 
Person means an individual firm, corporation, partnership, association, organization, or similar entity. 
Public safety communications center means the office responsible for receiving requests for emergency services and for dispatching appropriate police or fire personnel in the city. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-276. - Permit required; fee; application; false statements. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person operates, or causes to be operated, an alarm system without a valid alarm permit issued by the police chief. A separate permit is required for each alarm site. 
(b)  An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another person. A new permit and permit fee is required within thirty (30) days after: 
(1)  The installation of the alarm system; 
(2)  The expiration or revocation of a permit; or 
(3)  The transfer of a person occupying or in control of the alarm system at an alarm site. 
(c)  The annual fee for a permit (whether new or transferred) or permit renewal for an alarm site is twenty dollars ($20.00). No refund of a permit or permit renewal fee will be made. 
(d)  Each permit application must be made on a form provided by the police chief and must include the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone numbers of the person who will be the permit holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this article; 
(2)  The classification of the alarm site as residential, commercial, or multifamily dwelling or mini-warehouse or other similar premises; 
(3)  For each alarm system located at the alarm site, the purpose of the alarm system, i.e., burglary, fire, or other; 
(4)  The date of installation, or the date of the transfer of a person occupying or in control of the alarm system at an alarm site, whichever is applicable; and 
(5)  The name, address, and phone number of the alarm business monitoring and installing the alarm system installation and responsible for providing repair service to the alarm system. 
(e)  Any false statement of a material matter made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm permit shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a permit. 
(f)  All fees owed by an applicant must be paid before a permit may be issued or renewed. 
(g)  To the extent permitted by law, information contained in permit applications shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the city with access to such information. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-277. - Revocation of a permit. 
(a)  The police chief may suspend or revoke a permit if the police chief determines that the permit holder: 
(1)  Made a false statement of a material matter in the application for a permit; 
(2)  Failed to make timely payment of a false alarm fee assessed under section 11-283; or 
(3)  Has committed and has not remedied a violation of section 11-279. 
(b)  A permit holder commits an offense if the person operates the alarm system during a period in which the alarm permit is suspended or revoked. 
(c)  The police chief may refuse police response to an alarm system at an alarm site for which the alarm permit is revoked, suspended, or there is no permit, unless the permit holder has paid all false alarm fees. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-278. - Permit duration; renewal. 
A permit shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance, and must be renewed annually by submitting an updated application and permit fee to the police chief. The city shall attempt to notify each permit holder of the need to renew at least thirty (30) days before the expiration of the permit holder's permit. However, it is the responsibility of the permit holder to submit an application prior to the permit expiration date. Failure to renew will be classified as use of a nonpermitted alarm system and citations may be issued. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-279. - Proper alarm system operation and maintenance. 
A permit holder shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises in a manner that assures proper operation of the alarm system; 
(2)  Maintain the alarm system in a manner that will minimize false alarm notification; 
(3)  Respond or cause a representative to respond, within a reasonable period of time, to a request by the city to repair or inactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, and to provide access to the premises or to provide security for the premises; 
(4)  In the event that an alarm is activated on the premises, immediately report or have an alarm company charged with responsibility of notification immediately report such alarm to the public safety communications center. No owner, occupant, or alarm company shall delay or interfere with the immediate notification of the fire alarm to the public safety communications center; 
(5)  Refrain from manually activating an alarm for any reason other than the occurrence of any event that the alarm system was intended to report; 
(6)  Notify the public safety communications center prior to activating an alarm for maintenance purposes; and 
(7)  Maintain at each alarm site a complete set of written operating instructions for each alarm system along with special codes, combinations, or passwords included in these instructions. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-280. - Alarm activation, limitation and reset requirements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install or utilize any alarm system that causes an audible signal to be emitted for more than thirty (30) minutes after being activated or that emits a subsequent alarm without being reset. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-281. - Indirect alarm reporting. 
A person who is engaged in the business of relaying alarm notification to the city shall: 
(1)  Communicate the alarm notification to the city in a manner and form determined by the police chief; and 
(2)  Comply with the requirements of this chapter and any rules and regulations promulgated by the police chief. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-282. - Automatic alarm notification prohibited. 
An alarm system which transmits automatic alarm notification to the public safety communications center is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-283. - False alarm fees. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in subsections (b), (c), (d) and (e) below, the permit holder shall pay a false alarm fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each notification from any alarm system within any twelve-month period that is in excess of five (5) alarms. 
(b)  Upon adequate proof presented to the police chief of the date of installation of a new alarm system, no false alarm fee will be assessed during the first thirty (30) days after the system is put into service, and alarm notifications during that period will not be counted in determining when a false alarm fee will be assessed. 
(c)  An alarm notification will not be counted in determining when a service fee will be assessed if the permit holder can prove that the alarm notification was the result of a severe weather condition, such as a tornado, hurricane, earthquake, or other weather condition that causes physical damage to the alarm site, or the result of malfunction of the telephone lines for the transmission of the alarm signals, proof of the latter being documented upon the telephone company work orders or time stamped records from the alarm company showing the period of interrupted service. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-284. - Appeals from denial or revocation of permit; appeals from false alarm fees. 
(a)  If the police chief refuses to issue an initial permit or to renew a permit, or revokes a permit, the police chief shall send to the permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action and a statement of the permit holder's right to appeal. The permit holder may appeal the decision of the police chief to the city council by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice from the police chief. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city secretary stays an action of the police chief in revoking a permit until the city council makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the police chief is final. 
(b)  A permit holder may appeal assessment of a fee to the city council by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten (10) days after the imposition of the fee. 
(c)  The city council shall conduct a hearing and consider the evidence presented by any interested person. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply. The council shall make a decision on the basis of the preponderance of evidence presented at the hearing, including, but not limited to, evidence that a false alarm notification was caused by a defective part that has been repaired or replaced, or was caused by a criminal offense or attempted criminal offense; certification that the permit holder has received training on using the alarm system; or other evidence that the cause of a false alarm has been otherwise determined and corrected. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 11-285. - Offenses; penalties. 
A person commits an offense if he violates by commission or omission any provision of this article that imposes upon him a duty or responsibility, and is subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Secs. 11-286—11-299. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE LICENSE AND PERMIT FEES 
 
Sec. 11-300. - Permit fees. 
The following fees are hereby levied and assessed and shall be collected by the city for each permit issued by the state pursuant to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, for premises located within the city, which fee shall be paid by the permittee: 
(a)  Brewer's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a brewer's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 12.01, shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(b)  Nonresident brewer's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a nonresident brewer's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 13.01, shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(c)  Distiller's and rectifier's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a distiller's and rectifier's permits, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 14.01, shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(d)  Winery permit. The annual fee for each holder of a winery permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 16.01, shall be thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(e)  Wine bottlers permit. The annual fee for each holder of a wine bottlers permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 18.01, shall be one hundred twelve dollars and fifty cents ($112.50). 
(f)  Wholesaler's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a wholesaler's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 19.01, shall be nine hundred thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($937.50). 
(g)  General class B wholesaler's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a general class B wholesaler's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 20.01, shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(h)  Local class B wholesaler's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a local class B wholesaler's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 21.01, shall be thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(i)  Package store permit. The annual fee for each holder of a package store permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 22.01, shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(j)  Local distributor's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a local distributor's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 23.01, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(k)  Wine only package store permit. The annual fee for each holder of a wine only package store permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 24.01, shall be thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(l)  Wine and beer retailer's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a wine and beer retailer's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 25.01, shall be eighty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($87.50). 
(m)  Wine and beer retailer's off-premises permit. The annual fee for each holder of a wine and beer retailer's off-premises permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 26.01, shall be thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(n)  Mixed beverage permit. The annual fee for each holder of a mixed beverage permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 28.01, shall be three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00). A mixed beverage permit is exempt from the fee authorized by this section during the three-year period following the issuance of the permit. 
(o)  Mixed beverage late hours permit. The annual fee for each holder of a mixed beverage late hours permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 29.01, shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(p)  Daily temporary mixed beverage permit. The annual fee for each holder of a daily temporary mixed beverage permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 30.01, shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(q)  Caterer's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a caterer's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 31.01, shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(r)  Private club late hours permit. The annual fee for each holder of a private club late hours permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 33.01, shall be three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00). 
(s)  Nonresident seller's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a nonresident seller's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 37.01, shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(t)  Medicinal permit. The annual fee for each holder of a medicinal permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 39.01, shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(u)  Physician's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a physician's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 40.01, shall be fifty cents ($0.50). 
(v)  Beverage cartage permit. The annual fee for each holder of a beverage cartage permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 44.01, shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(w)  Bonded, warehouse permit. The annual fee for each holder of a bonded warehouse permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 46.01, shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(x)  Local industrial alcohol manufacturer's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a local industrial alcohol manufacturer's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 47.01, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(y)  Market research packager's permit. The annual fee for each holder of a market research packager's permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 46.01, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(z)  Minibar permit. The annual fee for each holder of a minibar permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 51.02, shall be: 
1.  One thousand dollars ($1000.00) for an original permit; 
2.  Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first renewal of a permit; 
3.  Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second renewal of a permit; and 
4.  Three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00) for the third and each subsequent renewal. 
(aa)  Package store tasting permit. The annual fee for each holder of a package store tasting permit, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 52.01, shall be twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50). 
(Ord. No. 502, § 1, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 11-301. - License fees. 
The following fees are hereby levied and assessed and shall be collected by the city for each license issued by the state pursuant to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, for premises located within the city, which fee shall be paid by the licensee: 
(a)  Manufacturer's license. The annual fee for each holder of a manufacturers license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 62.01, shall be as follows: 
1.  Three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00) for the first establishment. 
2.  Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second establishment. 
3.  Two thousand one hundred thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($2,137.50) for each of the third, fourth and fifth establishments. 
4.  Four thousand two hundred dollars ($4,200.00) for each establishment in excess of five (5). 
(b)  General distributor's license. The annual fee for each holder of a general distributor's license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 64.01, shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(c)  Local distributor's license. The annual fee for each holder of a local distributor's license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 65.01, shall be thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(d)  Branch distributor's license. The annual fee for each holder of a branch distributor's license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 66.01, shall be thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(e)  Importer's license. The annual fee for each holder of an importer's license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 67.01, shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(f)  Importer's carrier's license. The annual fee for each holder of an importer's carrier's license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 68.01, shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(g)  Retail dealer's on-premises license. The annual fee for each holder of a retail dealer's on-premises license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 69.01, shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(h)  Retail dealer's on-premises late hours license. The annual fee for each holder of a retail dealer's on-premises late hours license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 70.01, shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). 
(i)  Retail dealer's off-premises license. The annual fee for each holder of a retail dealer's off-premises license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 71.01, shall be thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(j)  Brewpub licensee. The annual fee for each holder of a brewpub license, as defined by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code § 74.01, shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 502, § 1, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 11-302. - Issuance of permit. 
Upon the payment of the applicable tax or fee prescribed in this chapter to the city secretary and exhibition to the city secretary of a permit duly issued by the state to the applicant or person paying such tax or fee, the city secretary shall, in the name of the city, issue and deliver to such applicant or person a permit to engage in the business in the city of the character described in and authorized by the permit from the state held by such applicant or person. The permit so issued in the name of the city shall authorize the conduct of such business upon the premises described in the permit from the state, and shall remain in force only so long as such permit from the state remains in force. 
(Ord. No. 502, § 1, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 11-303. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall fail to pay any tax or fee prescribed by this chapter and secure a permit before engaging in any business for which the payment of any such fee and securing of any such permit is required by the terms of this chapter, or who shall engage in any such business without holding an unrevoked or unexpired permit from the city authorizing the same shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 502, § 1, 11-14-00)  
Secs. 11-304—11-324. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE SALES 
 
Sec. 11-325. - Sale of liquor and beer prohibited in residential areas. 
The sale of liquor or beer shall be prohibited in all residential areas of the city. No permit shall be issued for the sale of liquor or beer in any residential area of the City of Everman, Texas. For the purpose of this section, the term "residential area" shall include all areas of the city presently zoned residential and all land hereinafter zoned residential, provided that this section shall not apply to any permit issued for premises zoned commercial at the time of such issuance and subsequently rezoned residential. 
(Ord. No. 678, § 1, 10-10-14)  
Sec. 11-326. - Regulations prohibiting sale of alcoholic beverages near a church, public or private school, or public hospital. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity who is engaged in the business of selling alcoholic beverages to sell the same at a place of business that is within: 
(1)  Three hundred (300) feet of a church, public or private school, or public hospital; or 
(2)  One thousand (1,000) feet of a private school if the city council receives a request from the governing body of the private school, and deems it appropriate given all circumstances. 
(b)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the church or public hospital shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. 
(c)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the public or private school shall be: 
(1)  In a direct line from the property line of the public or private school to the property line of the place of business, and in a direct line across intersections; or 
(2)  If the permit or license holder is located on or above the fifth story of a multistory building, in a direct line from the property line of the public or private school to the property line of the place of business, in a direct line across intersections, and vertically up the building at the property line to the base of the floor on which the permit or license holder is located. 
(d)  Every applicant for an original alcoholic beverage license or permit for a location with a door by which the public may enter the place of business of the applicant that is within one thousand (1,000) feet of the nearest property line of a public or private school, measured along street lines and directly across intersections, must give written notice of the application to officials of the public or private school before filing the application with the city and the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission. A copy of the notice must be submitted to the city and the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission with the application. This subsection does not apply to a permit or license covering a location where minors are prohibited from entering the premises under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 109.53. 
(e)  Subsection (a)(1) does not apply to the holder of a license or permit covering a premises that is located within three hundred (300) feet of a private school if the permit holder also holds a food and beverage certificate for the covered premises or if the permit covers a premises where minors are prohibited from entering under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 109.53. 
(1)  In this section, "private school" means a private school, including a parochial school, that offers a course of instruction for students in one (1) or more grades from kindergarten through grade 12 and has more than one hundred (100) students enrolled and attending courses at a single location. 
(f)  The city council may allow a variance to this section if it determines that the enforcement of the regulations in a particular instance is not in the best interest of the public, constitutes waste or inefficient use of land and resources, creates an undue hardship on the applicant for a license or permit, does not serve its intended purpose, is not effective or necessary, or for any other reason the city council determines, after consideration of the health, safety and welfare of the public and the equities of the situation, that the variance is in the best interest of the community. 
(g)  Subsection (a)(2) does not apply to the holder of a permit issued under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code Ch. 27, 31 or 72 who is operating on the premises of a private school or a permit covering a premises where minors are prohibited from entering under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 109.53 and that is located within one thousand (1,000) feet of a private school. 
(h)  To the extent applicable under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 109.331, the provisions of subsection (a)(1) relating to a public school also apply to a day-care center and child-care facility as those terms are defined in V.T.C.A. Human Resources Code § 42.002. 
(i)  As authorized by V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 109.36, the city council may allow a variance to this section if it determines that the enforcement of the regulations in a particular instance is not in the best interest of the public, constitutes waste or inefficient use of land and resources, creates an undue hardship on the applicant for a license or permit, does not serve its intended purpose, is not effective or necessary, or for any other reason the city council determines, after consideration of the health, safety and welfare of the public and the equities of the situation, that the variance is in the best interest of the community. 
(Ord. No. 678, § 1, 10-10-14)  
Sec. 11-327. - Permit or license required. 
(a)  No person shall sell alcoholic beverages in the City of Everman unless a permit or license authorizing such sale is first issued by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission and remains in effect. 
(b)  No permit or license shall be issued except in conformance with all state and city regulations. 
(c)  A fee for each issued permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the amount of which shall equal one-half (½) the state fee excluding surcharges collected under V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code § 5.56, is established and set forth in article VIII of this chapter. The permit or license fee shall be collected by the city when the permit or license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 678, § 1, 10-10-14)  
Sec. 11-328. - Hours for sale of alcoholic beverages, wine and beer, if permitted. 
If the sale of alcoholic beverages, wine or beer for off-premises consumption is permitted by the Code, the hours permitted for the sale of alcoholic beverages, wine or beer shall be governed by V.T.C.A. Alcohol Beverage Code §§ 105.04 and 105.05, as now written or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 678, § 1, 10-10-14)  
Sec. 11-329. - Regulation of food and beverage certificate holders. 
(a)  A person or entity engaged in the sale of mixed beverages in a restaurant under a food and beverage certificate shall, on an annual basis, on a day coinciding with the date that such information is furnished to the State of Texas, file with the city secretary an affidavit showing the gross receipts and sales of the business. The affidavit shall contain a statement reflecting the gross receipts attributable to the premises and the gross receipts attributable to the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  The food and beverage certificate holder shall also file with the city secretary, on an annual basis, on a date coinciding with the date such information is furnished to the State of Texas, the gross receipts and figures furnished to the State of Texas for sales tax and alcoholic beverage tax purposes. This provision applies to restaurants, cafes, cafeterias or eating establishments and to a permittee of a federal or state agency. 
The food and beverage certificate holder shall also furnish receipts from suppliers upon request of the city secretary. Such receipts shall reflect current operations and operations for the previous twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 678, § 1, 10-10-14)  
Chapter 12 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal court, § 9.01 et seq. 
Cross reference— General penalty for Code violations, § 1-7; emergency management, Ch. 6; offenses, Ch. 13; police, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, V.T.C.A. Government Code, § 29.001 et seq. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), adopted July 23, 2019, repealed the former Ch. 12, and enacted a new Ch. 12 as set out herein. The former Ch. 12 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1977 §§ 1-136, 1-137, 1-140; Ord. No. 417, § 1, adopted June 19, 1990; Ord. No. 460, §§ 1, 2, adopted November 14, 1996; Ord. No. 489, §§ I—III, adopted December 14, 1999. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Municipal court of record created. 
(a)  There is hereby created the "Municipal Court of Record in the City of Everman, Texas." The municipal court of record shall be comprised of as many divisions as the city council deems necessary. The municipal court that is operating on the date that this ordinance is adopted shall transfer its pending cases to the municipal court of record in the City of Everman, Texas and be abolished, and all cases arising from alleged actions or inactions occurring after the date of the adoption of this ordinance shall be filed within the new municipal court of record for disposition. 
(b)  The court shall have no term and may sit at any time for the transaction of business of the court. Where the term "municipal court" is used in the City's Code of Ordinances, it shall mean the municipal court of record created herein. Any provision of the city's charter, ordinances or state law that is applicable to a municipal court shall be applicable to the municipal court of record created herein unless the provision is in conflict with or inconsistent with Chapters 29 or 30 of the Texas Government Code, as amended, which governs municipal courts of record. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-2. - Jurisdictional limits of court. 
(a)  The court has all such jurisdiction as is provided to municipal courts by Sections 29.003 and 30.005, Texas Government Code. 
(b)  The court has concurrent jurisdiction with a justice court in any precinct in which the municipality is located in criminal cases that arise within the territorial limits of the City of Everman and are punishable by fine only. 
(c)  The court has civil jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing municipal ordinances enacted under Subchapter A, Chapter 214, Texas Local Government Code, or Subchapter E, Chapter 683, Texas Transportation Code. 
(d)  The court has concurrent jurisdiction with a district court or a county court at law under Subchapter B, Chapter 54, Texas Local Government Code, within the city's territorial limits and property owned by the city located in the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing health and safety and nuisance abatement ordinances. 
(e)  The court has authority to issue: 
(1)  Search warrants for the purpose of investigating a health and safety or nuisance abatement ordinance violation; and 
(2)  Seizure warrants for the purpose of securing, removing, or demolishing the offending property and removing the debris from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-3. - Municipal judge appointment. 
(a)  The municipal court of record shall be presided over by a judge, who shall be known as the "municipal judge." The judge shall be appointed by the city council for a term of two (2) years and shall be entitled to a salary set by the city council. The amount of the judge's salary may not be diminished during the judge's term of office. The salary may not be based directly or indirectly on fines, fees, or costs collected by the court. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of this ordinance, the current presiding judge of the Municipal Court of Everman shall become the judge of the Municipal Court of Record in the City of Everman. The initial term shall expire two (2) years from the date of his/her last appointment by the city council as judge of the municipal court. At the conclusion of the initial term described herein, all succeeding terms of the municipal judge shall be two (2) years from the date of the last appointment by the city council. 
(c)  The municipal judge must: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States; 
(2)  Be a resident of this state; 
(3)  Be a licensed attorney in good standing; 
(4)  Have two (2) or more years of experience in the practice of law in this state; and as may be amended by Texas Government Code Sec. 30.00006. 
(d)  A person may not serve as a municipal judge if the person is otherwise employed by the municipality. A municipal judge who accepts other employment with the municipality vacates the judicial office. 
(e)  If a vacancy occurs in the office of municipal judge, the city council shall adopt an ordinance appointing a qualified person to fill the office for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(f)  There may also be alternate judges appointed by the city council, subject to the same qualifications, who shall have all the powers and shall discharge all the duties of a municipal judge while serving as municipal judge. In the event of the appointment of any such alternate judge, the regular municipal judge shall be titled and known as "presiding judge." Each alternate judge shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. If the presiding judge is temporarily absent due to illness, family death, continuing legal or judicial education programs, or any other reason, he/she shall select one (1) of the alternate judge(s) to serve during his/her absence. 
(g)  Upon the adoption of this ordinance, the current alternate judge(s) of the Municipal Court of Everman shall become the alternate judge(s) of the Municipal Court of Record in the City of Everman. The initial term shall expire two (2) years from the date of his/her last appointment by the city council as alternate judge of the municipal court. At the conclusion of the initial term described herein, all succeeding terms of the alternate municipal judge shall be two (2) years from the date of the last appointment by the city council. 
(h)  The municipal judges may exchange benches and act for each other in any proceeding pending in the court. An act performed by any of the judges is binding on all parties to the proceeding. 
(i)  The municipal judge(s) shall take judicial notice of state law and the ordinances and corporate limits of the municipality. 
(j)  The judge(s) of the municipal court may grant writs of mandamus, injunction, attachment, and other writs necessary to the enforcement of the court's jurisdiction and may issue writs of habeas corpus in cases in which the offense charged is within the jurisdiction of the court. 
(k)  A municipal judge is a magistrate and may issue administrative search warrants. 
(l)  A municipal judge may be removed from office by the city council as provided by the Everman Charter section 9.03 and: 
(1)  As provided by Section 1-a, Article V, Texas Constitution; or 
(2)  For the reasons and by the procedure provided in Subchapter B, Chapter 21, Texas Local Government Code. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-4. - Court rules. 
The Code of Criminal Procedure and the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure, as modified by Chapter 30, Texas Government Code, govern the trial of cases before the municipal court of record. The court may make and enforce all rules of practice and procedure necessary to expedite the trial of cases before the court that are not inconsistent with law. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-5. - Municipal court clerk appointment, powers and duties. 
The city manager of the city shall appoint a clerk of the municipal court of record who may hire, direct, and remove the personnel authorized in the city's annual budget for the clerk's office. The clerk or the clerk's deputies shall keep the records of the municipal court of record, issue process, and generally perform the duties for the court that a clerk of the county court at law exercising criminal jurisdiction is required by law to perform for that court. In addition, the clerk or the clerk's deputies shall maintain an index of all court judgments in the same manner as county clerks are required by law to prepare for criminal cases arising in county courts. The clerk shall perform the duties in accordance with statutes, and the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-6. - Preserving court record. 
For the purpose of recording the proceedings and preserving a record in all cases tried before the municipal court of record, a good quality electronic recording device shall be used. When the recording device is used, a court reporter need not be present at the trial to certify the reporter's record. The recording shall be kept and stored for a 20-day period beginning the day after a final order has been entered in the proceeding, upon completion of the trial, or after the denial of motion for a new trial, whichever occurs last. If a case is appealed, the proceedings shall be transcribed from the recording by an official court reporter. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-7. - Court facilities and seal. 
(a)  The city council shall provide courtrooms, jury rooms, offices, office furniture, libraries, law books, and other facilities and supplies that the city council determines necessary for the proper operation of the municipal court of record. 
(b)  The city council shall provide the municipal court of record with a seal that contains the phrase "Municipal Court of The City of EVERMAN, Texas." The seal's use must conform to Article 45.012 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-8. - Complaints and pleadings. 
Proceedings in the municipal court of record shall commence by complaint, as provided by state law. Complaints and pleadings must substantially conform to the relevant provisions of Chapters 212 and 45, Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-9. - Prosecution. 
Prosecution in the municipal court of record shall be conducted as provided by Article 45.201, Code of Criminal Procedure. Prosecution may be performed by the city attorney or another lawyer designated as municipal prosecutor/deputy city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-10. - Jury. 
(a)  A person who is brought before the municipal court of record and who is charged with an offense is entitled to be tried by a jury of six (6) persons. Trial by jury, including the summoning of jurors, must substantially conform to Chapter 45, Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The court clerk shall supervise the selection of persons for jury service. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-11. - Appeal from judgment or conviction. 
(a)  A defendant has the right of appeal from a judgment or conviction in the municipal court of record. The State of Texas has the right to appeal as provided by Article 44.01, Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The appellate court shall determine each appeal from a municipal court of record conviction and each appeal from the state on the basis of the errors that are set forth in the appellant's motion and that are presented in the clerk's record and reporter's record prepared from the proceedings leading to the conviction or appeal. An appeal from the municipal court of record shall not be by trial de novo. 
(c)  To perfect an appeal, the appellant must file a motion for new trial not later than the tenth day after the date on which the judgment and sentence are rendered. The motion must be in writing and must be filed with the clerk of the municipal court of record. The motion must set forth the points of error of which the appellant complains. The motion or an amended motion may be amended by leave of court at any time before action on the motion is taken, but not later than the twentieth day after the date on which the original or amended motion is filed. The court may for good cause extend the time for filing or amending, but the extension may not exceed ninety (90) days from the original filing deadline. If the court does not act on the motion before the expiration of the thirty (30) days allowed for determination of the motion, the original or amended motion is overruled by operation of law. 
(d)  To perfect an appeal, the appellant must also give notice of the appeal. If the appellant requests a hearing on the motion for new trial, the appellant may give the notice of appeal orally in open court on the overruling of the motion. If there is no hearing, the appellant must give a written notice of appeal and must file the notice with the court no later than the tenth day after the date on which the motion is overruled. The court may for good cause extend that time period, but the extension may not exceed ninety (90) days from the original filing deadline. 
(e)  The fee for the preparation of the clerk's record, which does not include the fee the defendant must pay for an actual transcript of the proceedings, is twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The clerk shall note the payment of the fee on the docket of the court. If the case is reversed on appeal, the fee shall be refunded to the defendant.  
Sec. 12-12. - Appeal bond and record on appeal. 
(a)  If the defendant is not in custody, the defendant may not take an appeal until the defendant files an appeal bond with the municipal court of record. The bond must be approved by the court and must be filed not later than the tenth day after the date on which the motion for new trial is overruled. If the defendant is in custody, the defendant shall be committed to jail unless the defendant posts the appeal bond. 
(b)  The appeal bond must be in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or double the amount of fines and costs adjudged against the defendant, whichever is greater. 
(c)  The bond must: 
(1)  State that the defendant was convicted in the case and has appealed; 
(2)  Be conditioned on the defendant's immediate and daily personal appearance in the court to which the appeal is taken; and 
(3)  Be in the form of either a cash bond, or surety bond naming two (2) or more good and sufficient sureties as approved by the clerk of the court. 
(d)  After an order overruling a motion for new trial, the defendant shall give written notice of appeal and pay a fee for the preparation of the clerk's record of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) not later than ten (10) days after the date on which the motion is overruled. The court shall note the payment of the fee on the docket of the court. If the case is reversed on appeal, the fee shall be refunded to the defendant. The defendant shall pay the fee for the preparation of the clerk's record and the fee for an actual transcription of the proceedings. 
(e)  The record on appeal must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of a transcript in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-13. - Statement of facts. 
(a)  A reporter's record included in the record on appeal must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of a reporter's record in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The appellant shall pay for the reporter's record. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-14. - Bills of exception. 
Bills of exception must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of bills of exception in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-15. - Transfer of record. 
(a)  Not later than the sixtieth day after the date on which the notice of appeal is given or filed, the parties must file the following with the clerk of the municipal court: 
(1)  The reporter's record; 
(2)  A written description of material to be included in the clerk's record in addition to the required material; and 
(3)  Any material to be included in the clerk's record that is not in the custody of the clerk. 
(b)  On completion of the record, the municipal judge shall approve the record in the manner provided for record completion, approval, and notification in the court of appeals. 
(c)  After the court approves the record, the clerk shall promptly forward the record to the appellate court clerk. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-16. - New trial. 
(a)  Each party, on filing the party's brief on appeal with the appellate court clerk, shall deliver a copy of the brief to the municipal judge. 
(b)  The trial court shall decide from the briefs of the parties whether the appellant should be permitted to withdraw the notice of appeal and be granted a new trial by the court. The court may grant a new trial at any time before the record is filed with the appellate court. 
(c)  If the appellate court awards a new trial to the appellant, the case stands as if a new trial had been granted by the municipal court of record. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-17. - Certificate of appellate proceedings. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the certificate of appellate proceedings from the appellate court clerk, the clerk of the municipal court of record shall file the certificate with the papers in the case and note the certificate on the case docket. 
(b)  If the municipal court of record judgment is affirmed, to enforce the judgment the court may: 
(1)  Forfeit the bond of the defendant; 
(2)  Issue a Writ of Capias for the defendant; 
(3)  Issue an execution against the defendant's property; 
(4)  Order a refund for the defendant's costs; or 
(5)  Conduct an indigency hearing at the court's discretion. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-18. - Texas code of criminal procedure, article 102.017, adopted. 
The city hereby adopts Article 102.017(b), (c), (d) and (e) of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure; Municipal Court Building Security Fund, as applicable to a municipality. This section only applies to conviction of offenses (misdemeanors) committed on or after August 28, 1995. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Sec. 12-19. - Municipal court technology fund. 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund, hereinafter referred to as the "fund," pursuant to Article 102.0172, Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. The fund may be maintained in an interest-bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(b)  Amount of fee; assessment; collection. 
(1)  The fee shall be in the amount of four dollars ($4.00). 
(2)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the City of Everman Municipal Court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
a.  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
b.  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication, disposition, or community supervision; or 
c.  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(3)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after September 1, 1999. 
(4)  The court clerk shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the finance director of the City of Everman, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology fund. 
(c)  Designated use of the fund; administration. 
(1)  The fund shall be used only to finance the purchase of technological enhancements for the Municipal Court of the City of Everman, Texas, including: 
a.  Computer systems; 
b.  Computer networks; 
c.  Computer hardware; 
d.  Computer software; 
e.  Imaging systems; 
f.  Electronic kiosks; 
g.  Electronic ticket writers; or 
h.  Docket management systems. 
(2)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Council of the City of Everman. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 2(Att. A), 7-23-19)  
Chapter 13 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty for Code violations, § 1-7; emergency management, Ch. 6; municipal court, Ch. 12; police, Ch. 16; traffic, Ch. 19. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Discharging of firearms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any gun, pistol or firearm of any kind, or to discharge an air rifle or air pistol of any description, by whatever name known, that by means of compressed air, compressed gas, springs or any other means is capable of discharging and propelling shots, pellets or any solid object for a distance of greater than fifty (50) feet, within the city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 11-31)  
Sec. 13-2. - Firearms in city buildings; prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a peace officer, to carry a firearm in any city building, regardless of whether or not the person is duly licensed by the state to carry a concealed handgun. 
(b)  The term "city building" as used in this section is defined as any building or portion of a building owned, occupied, leased, or controlled by the City of Everman, Texas, for city operations and activities. The term does not include any public or private driveway, street, sidewalk or walkway, parking garage, or other parking area. 
(c)  The term "handgun" as used in this section is defined as any firearm that is designed, made or adapted to be fired with one hand, and the term "concealed handgun" as used in this section is defined as a handgun, the presence of which is not openly discernible to the ordinary observation of a reasonable person. 
(d)  The terms "gun," "pistol," "rifle," and "firearm" as used in this section shall not only be defined to include all percussion weapons, but shall include all air guns, air pistols, air rifles, and all other firearms using air pressure to propel a projectile. 
(Ord. No. 461, § 1, 1-9-96) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 461, § 1, adopted Jan. 9, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification as § 13-2 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 13-3. - Criminal trespass. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain on or in the property of another without effective consent of the owner, the person in control, or the owner's agent if the person: 
(1)  Has notice that the entry was forbidden; 
(2)  Has notice that permission is withdrawn; or 
(3)  Receives notice to depart from the owner, the person in control, or the owner's agent but fails to do so, 
and remains on the property after a Texas Peace Officer orders the person to leave. 
(Ord. No. 635, § 1, 12-14-10)  
Sec. 13-4. - Loitering with a criminal purpose. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to loiter in or near any street or place open to the public or to which the general public has access to for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose, including, but not limited to, the front or immediate area surrounding any convenience store, retail store, or other business establishment, in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of committing or inducing, enticing, or provoking another to commit assault, reckless damage, criminal mischief, or disorderly conduct. 
(b)  In this section, the term "loiter" means "to remain, to delay, or to linger in one (1) place with an apparent harmful purpose, such as to: 
(1)  Establish control over an identifiable area; 
(2)  Obstruct or impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic; 
(3)  Intimidate others from exiting or entering an establishment; or 
(4)  Conceal illegal activities; 
and at a time not usual for law abiding individuals or under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm for the safety of persons or property within the vicinity. 
(c)  The terms "assault", "reckless damage", "criminal mischief", and "disorderly conduct" shall have the same meanings as set out in the Texas Penal Code. 
(Ord. No. 635, § 1, 12-14-10)  
Secs. 13-5—13-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MINORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 13-51—13-71. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW HOURS FOR MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No.728, § 1, adopted March 12, 2019, amended Div. 2, §§ 13-72—13-77, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 449, adopted July 12, 1994; Ord. No. 499, adopted Sept. 15, 2000; Ord. No. 621, § 1, adopted March 10, 2009; Ord. No. 658, § 1, adopted June 12, 2012. 
 
Sec. 13-72. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following words are defined as follows: 
(a)  Curfew hours: 
(1)  11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday; 
(2)  12:01 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday; and 
(3)  8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. 
(b)  Emergency: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. The term includes, but is not limited to; fire, natural disaster, vehicular accident, or a serious medical condition of sudden onset. 
(c)  Establishment: A privately owned place of business open to the public, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. 
(d)  Guardian: Any person, or public or private agency that has been given custody of minor by a court order. 
(e)  Minor: Any person under seventeen (17) years of age. 
(f)  Operator: Any individual, firm association, partnership, corporation or any other entity operating, managing or conducting an establishment. 
(g)  Parent: A mother or father whether biological or adoptive, step mother/father or foster mother/father or a court appointed guardian or other person eighteen (18) years of age or older, authorized by a court order or a parent or guardian to have care and custody of a minor. 
(h)  Public place: Any location which the public, or a substantial number of members of the public have access to and includes, but is not limited to; streets, highways, parks, sidewalks, alleys, common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transit facilities, shopping centers, shops, restaurants, theaters, and game rooms. 
(i)  Remain: To linger, stay or fail to leave a location when requested to do so by a police officer, owner, operator or other person in control of premises. 
(j)  Serious bodily injury: A bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death, or causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Sec. 13-73. - Violations and offenses. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this ordinance for a minor to remain, walk, run, stand, drive or ride about in or upon any public place in the city during the curfew hours defined in paragraphs 13-72(a)(1)(2)(3) above. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this ordinance for a parent or guardian to knowingly permit, or by insufficient control allow a minor to remain in any public place or remain on the premises of any establishment with the city limits during the curfew hours defined in paragraphs 13-72(a)(1)(2)(3) above. 
3.  The owner, operator or employee of an establishment commits an offense of this ordinance if he/she allows a minor to remain upon the premises of an establishment during the curfew hours defined in paragraphs 13-72(a)(1)(2)(3) above. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Sec. 13-74. - Defenses. 
It is a defense to prosecution under this division that: 
(1)  The minor was accompanied by his or her parent or guardian; 
(2)  The minor was accompanied by someone aged eighteen (18) or older designated by his or her parent or guardian; 
(3)  The minor was on an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(4)  The minor was on an errand made necessary by an emergency; 
(5)  The minor was in a motor vehicle involved in intrastate or interstate travel, for which passage through the curfew area was the most direct route; 
(6)  The minor was engaged in a lawful employment activity or was going directly to or coming directly from his or her place of lawful employment without any detour or stop; 
(7)  The minor was on the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor where the minor had permission from his or her guardian and if the next-door neighbor did not complain about the minor's presence; 
(8)  The minor was attending s school, government or civic organization sponsored event, a religious activity or other recreational activity sponsored and supervised by adults, or coming or going from such an event without detour or stop; 
(9)  The minor is married or had been married or had the disabilities of minority removed in accordance with Chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code; 
(10)  The minor was exercising his or her First Amendment Rights protected by the United States Constitution, including, but not limited to, the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and freedom of assembly; or any rights and protections afforded by the Texas Constitution; 
(11)  With respect to the hours of 8:30 a.m.—3:00 p.m. specified as curfew hours in section 13-72(a)(3) above, it shall be a defense to prosecution if the offense occurred during the school summer vacation break of the school in which the minor is enrolled or on a holiday observed by the closure of the school in which the minor is enrolled or that the minor has graduated from high school or received a high school equivalency certificate; 
(12)  It shall be a defense to prosecution under section 13-73(c) if the owner, operator or employee of an establishment notified the Everman Police Department a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Sec. 13-75. - Enforcement. 
Before taking any enforcement action under this ordinance, a police officer shall ask the alleged offender's age and reason for being in a public place during curfew hours. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest unless the officer believes that an offense has occurred and none of the defenses to prosecution set forth in section 13-74 above are applicable to the situation. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Sec. 13-76. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this ordinance is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  When required by Section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over the minor and refer the matter to juvenile court. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Sec. 13-77. - Re-adoption. 
In accordance with section 370.002 of the Texas Local Government Code, before the third anniversary of the adoption of this ordinance and every third year thereafter, if it is continued to be required by state law, the city council shall review the regulations contained herein and conduct a public hearing on the need to continue, abolish or modify this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 728, § 1, 3-12-19)  
Secs. 13-78—13-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - AEROSOL PAINT AND GRAFFITI 
 
Sec. 13-100. - Definitions. 
In this article the following words, terms and phrases shall have their respective meanings as described below: 
Aerosol means an aerosolized paint product, including, but not limited to, a clear or pigmented lacquer or finish. 
Graffiti means an unauthorized inscription, work, signature, symbol, design, or other marking which is etched, written, painted, drawn, or applied in any other way to a structure, building, or property. 
Minor means a person younger than seventeen (17) years of age. 
Owner means a person who owns or is in control of property. 
Unauthorized means without the permission of the owner of property. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-101. - Possession of aerosol paint. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if the minor possesses aerosol paint. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a) that the minor possessed the aerosol paint while the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied or supervised by a parent or guardian; 
(2)  Accompanied or supervised by a teacher in connection with a school project; 
(3)  Supervised during the minor's regular employment; 
(4)  On the property on which the minor lives; or 
(5)  Engaged in an organized event sponsored or supervised by the city, a school, a church, or some other officially recognized entity or organization. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-102. - Graffiti declared a nuisance. 
Graffiti visible from public or private property other than the property on which the graffiti exists is hereby declared a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-103. - Placement of graffiti. 
A person commits an offense if the person places graffiti on property. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-104. - Failure to remove graffiti. 
An owner of property commits an offense if the owner fails to remove graffiti from the owner's property if the graffiti is visible from public or private property other than the property on which the graffiti exists. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-105. - Notice and abatement by owner. 
(a)  The city must notify the property owner of a violation of this article, and must give the owner the opportunity to remove the graffiti before: 
(1)  Issuing a citation for a violation of this section 13-104; or 
(2)  Entering the property and doing the work necessary to abate the nuisance. 
(b)  Notice must be given: 
(1)  In writing and personally delivered to the owner; 
(2)  By letter addressed to the owner's address as listed on the most recent ad valorem tax rolls; or 
(3)  If personal service cannot be obtained or the owner's address is unknown: 
a.  By publication in the official newspaper at least twice within ten (10) consecutive days; or 
b.  By posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or 
c.  If the property does not contain any buildings, by posting the notice on a placard or sign attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates. 
(c)  Notice shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the record owner; 
(2)  An identification, which is not required to be a legal description, of the property upon which the violation is located; 
(3)  A statement describing the violation and the work necessary to correct the violation; 
(4)  A statement advising the owner that if the work is not completed within fourteen days, the city will complete the work and assess the cost of the work to the owner; 
(5)  A statement that if the city performs the work and the owner fails to pay the cost, a lien may be placed on the property; 
(6)  A statement that the owner may submit a written request to the city secretary for an informal hearing before the city manager or her designee within five (5) days after receiving notice of a violation to contest whether the violation exists; and 
(7)  A statement that the city may, at any time, file a criminal misdemeanor complaint in municipal court with a maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day the violation exists, in addition to or in lieu of any other remedy provided by law. 
(d)  For purposes of this article notice is deemed to have been received: 
(1)  For personal service, on the day notice was personally delivered to the owner; 
(2)  For mailed notice, three days after written notice was mailed to the owner; 
(3)  For notice by publication, on the date that the last notice is published in the official newspaper; or 
(4)  For notice by posting, the day of posting. 
(e)  A citation for violation of section 13-104 may be issued fourteen (14) calendar days after notice of the violation is received. 
(f)  If the owner does not comply with this article by the fourteenth calendar day after notice is deemed received, the city may enter the property or authorize another to enter the property and do or cause to be done all work necessary to abate the graffiti. 
(g)  If the city performs the abatement work pursuant to subsection (f), it shall initially pay for the work done, and shall charge the expenses to the owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-106. - Informal hearing. 
If within five (5) days after receiving notice, the property owner files a written request with the city secretary according to section 13-105(c)(6), the city manager or her designee shall hold an informal hearing. Unless the owner requests and is granted an immediate hearing and waives the right to notice, notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be sent to the owner by certified mail. At the hearing, the owner may provide evidence or testimony that a violation does not exist and abatement is not warranted. After the hearing, the city manager or her designee may determine whether a violation requiring abatement exists. Failure of the property owner to timely request a hearing or to appear at a hearing shall constitute a waiver of any right to challenge the abatement of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-107. - Assessment of expenses; lien. 
(a)  The city may assess expenses incurred by the city for the abatement of graffiti pursuant to section 13-105 against the real property on which the work was done. 
(b)  To obtain a lien against the property, the city shall file with the county clerk of the county in which the property is located a statement of expenses and a copy of the notice that the city provided to the owner. 
(c)  The lien is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent per annum on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. 
(d)  The lien is inferior only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. A lien may not be filed against real estate protected by the homestead provisions of the Texas Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-108. - Public service by offenders. 
In any case in which a defendant is found guilty of an offense involving placing graffiti or possessing aerosol spray, the municipal court judge shall consider imposing a public service assignment to clean up graffiti, in place of or in addition to a fine. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Sec. 13-109. - Assistance in removal of graffiti. 
If an owner needs assistance in removing graffiti from the owner's property, the owner shall submit a written request for assistance to the city manager or the city manager's designee within three (3) days after receiving notice under section 13-105. The city manager or designee shall respond in writing, telling the property owner whether or not assistance is available. The city shall not issue a citation for a violation of section 13-104 until fourteen (14) days after the city responds in writing. 
(Ord. No. 473, § 1, 7-14-98)  
Chapter 14 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes:

No. 519, §§ 1, 3, adopted April 9, 2002.
