ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverage shall be defined to include any alcohol and any beverage containing more than one-half (½) of one (1) percent of alcohol by volume which is capable of use for beverage, either alone or when diluted. 
City park shall be defined to be any park, playground or recreational area owned, leased, operated or under the control of the city. This definition shall include but is not limited to any athletic field, swimming pool, gymnasium, tennis court, and other similar facility owned by the city. 
City sports field shall mean the Johnson Park Baseball fields or the Clyde Pittman Park Football field. 
Everman youth association shall mean any nonprofit entity registered with the Texas Secretary of State that is formed for the purpose of providing youth recreational activities and that serves only youth from the Everman School District. 
Other youth association shall mean any nonprofit entity registered with the Texas Secretary of State that is formed for the purpose of providing youth recreational activities and that serves youth from areas outside of the Everman School District. 
Renter shall mean, when used in this chapter, any person, association or other entity that applies for rental of a city sports field, submits all necessary materials, is approved by the city and enters into a duly executed rental agreement. 
(Ord. No. 680, § 1, 11-11-14; Ord. No. 713, § 1, 7-11-17)  
Secs. 14-2—14-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PARK USE RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 14-21. - Rules and regulations. 
The following regulations and restrictions are prescribed for the use of city parks: 
(1)  Alcoholic beverages prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in any city park. 
(2)  Riding, driving, or walking horses in city park. Except on designated horse trails, it shall be unlawful for any person to walk, drive or ride a horse or horses within any city park. 
(3)  Riding or driving off-road motorized vehicles in a city park. Except on designated off-road trails, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or ride an off-road vehicle within any city park. For the purposes of this section, an off-road vehicle is a motorized vehicle designed and equipped for use on surfaces other than paved roadway with such definition to specifically include off-road motor bikes, go-carts, and dune buggies. 
(4)  Vehicular traffic prohibited in certain areas. Except in designated overflow parking areas, it shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to stand, stop, park or cross onto or into any portion of a city park other than upon a roadway or parking area so designated for such purposes. 
(5)  Time limitations on public use of park. Except for a city sponsored event, it shall be unlawful for any person to use, enter into or be within a city park during the hours of 11:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. 
(6)  Littering, vandalism, and graffiti. Littering, criminal mischief, and graffiti are hereby prohibited in any city park. Littering shall include leaving trash or other items by persons picnicking within a city park and not placing trash and other items in appropriate trash receptacles provided in such park. Criminal mischief or vandalism and graffiti shall have the meaning ascribed to those words and offenses in the Texas Penal Code, as amended. 
(7)  Firearms prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or about himself or to discharge a gun, pistol, rifle, or other firearm within any city park except that a person duly licensed by the state to carry a concealed handgun may carry a concealed handgun in accordance with state law. 
(8)  Bicycles, skates, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle, scooter, skate board, in-line skates, or roller skates on any tennis court or basketball court owned or leased by the city, or in any other public areas posted by the city. 
(9)  Smoking prohibited in splash pad area. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in the designated splash pad area. 
(10)  Glass containers prohibited in city parks. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess a glass container in a city park. 
(11)  Defacing public property. 
a.  No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate, or deface any structure, monument, statue, vase, fountain, wall, fence, railing, vehicle, bench, building or other property located in any city park. 
b.  No person shall cut, break, deface, injure, or remove the trees, shrubs, plants, grasses, or turf within any city park. 
(12)  Wild animals. It shall be unlawful to catch, injure, kill, strike, or attempt to strike with any object or weapon any animals within a city park. 
(13)  Climbing, etc., prohibited. It shall be unlawful to climb any trees or walk, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains, walls, fences, railings, vehicles, basketball posts or nets, soccer posts or nets, volleyball posts or nets, or any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes in any city park. 
(14)  Pollution of waters. It shall be unlawful to throw, discharge to, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such waters any substance, matter, or anything liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said waters. 
(15)  Children under a certain age. No person under twelve (12) years of age shall be permitted in any city park without being accompanied by an adult over the age of eighteen (18). 
(16)  Splash pad. Splash pad operation shall be from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Food or drink of any kind shall not be permitted in the splash pad. 
(17)  Erecting structures prohibited. 
a.  No person shall place or erect any structure, sign, bulletin board, post, pole, or advertising of any kind in a city park. 
b.  No person shall attach to any tree, shrub, fence, railing, post, or structure within any city park, any sign, bulletin board, or other advertising device of any kind. 
c.  The prohibitions contained in subsections a. and b. of this section shall not be applicable to persons acting pursuant to and with the written authorization of the director of public works or his designee. 
(18)  Projectile devices. No person shall possess, fire, or discharge a device capable of propelling a projectile, including without limitation, any air gun, pistol, bow and arrow, cross bow, or sling shot in a city park; provided, however, the director of public works may permit the temporary occurrence of such activities in a city park for special programs and events. 
(19)  Sale of merchandise. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any food, drinks, confections, merchandise, or services in any park or playground unless such person has a written agreement or permit issued by the city permitting the sale of such items in such park or playground. This section shall have no application to social organizations selling items to their own members, or at functions sanctioned by the city. 
(20)  Sound amplification. It shall be unlawful to use any type of sound amplification system in a city park without the written consent of the director of public works. 
(21)  Pets prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any animal considered a pet in any city park. Pets shall include all dogs, cats, snakes, monkeys, and all other animals except for animals that are used for service of the disabled. 
(Ord. No. 680, § 1, 11-11-14)  
Sec. 14-22. - Variances. 
The city manager or his/her designee is authorized to issue special permits or grant variances to the provisions of this article. The zoning board of adjustment will make recommendations regarding variances to the city manager. A special permit variance shall not be granted by the city manager unless a written request is submitted which demonstrates: 
(1)  Special circumstances exist which are peculiar to the applicant's ability to utilize city parks; and 
(2)  That use of the city park by other groups or individuals will not be adversely affected by granting the special permit variance. 
(Ord. No. 680, § 1, 11-11-14)  
Secs. 14-23—14-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SPORTS FIELD RECREATIONAL AREAS 
 
Sec. 14-30. - Everman youth association rental of city sports fields. 
The city sports fields consist of Johnson Park Baseball field and Clyde Pittman Park Football field. Rental of these city sports fields and the execution of a rental contract will be allowed on the following basis: 
(1)  Any Everman youth association will be allowed to rent either of the city sports fields and associated grounds, structures and parking areas for a season covering such dates and including such games and practices as are specified in the application, subject to approval by the city manager or his designee. Everman youth associations may apply for such rental by submitting a completed application in accordance with the provisions of this article along with all required information, including proof of state approved nonprofit corporation or association status and payment of all necessary deposits and fees, to the city manager's office no earlier than sixty (60) days prior to the start of the first practice of the requested sports season. Other youth associations may also apply for rental of the fields, but scheduling preference will be given to Everman youth associations. 
(2)  If multiple applications are received for a specific period or season, the city will grant rental of the field to the first Everman youth association submitting all of the required information. In the event that more than one (1) Everman youth association submits all required information at the same date and time, the acceptance and approval of the application and rental will be determined by drawing of numbers. If no Everman youth association submits an application for a particular period or season, applications will be opened up to other youth associations. 
(3)  To be deemed complete an application must include all of the following: 
a.  Completed application form; 
b.  Payment of applicable fees/deposits as set forth below; 
c.  Proof of state approved nonprofit corporation or association status; 
d.  Liability insurance in amounts set by the city manager; 
e.  Play and practice schedule listing date and time of each practice session and each game for the season; and 
f.  Roster indicating number of teams, number of players, and name and address of all players for the season. 
(4)  After approval of the application, a rental contract will be prepared by the city and executed by both parties prior to any use of the sports fields. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-31. - Rental of sports fields by other youth associations or persons. 
Other youth associations or other persons or entities may rent the city sports fields for such dates and times as approved by the city manager or his designee after submission of an application meeting the requirements set forth in section 14-30 above and payment of the applicable deposits and fees set forth in this chapter. Scheduling preference shall be given to Everman youth associations. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-32. - Concession areas. 
(a)  During such times that any renter is approved for rental of a particular city sports field and is operating under a valid rental contract, the renter shall have exclusive use of any concession area located at the applicable city sports field and may place a lock on the concession area (a key must be provided to the city manager's office). The renter shall not remove any existing property from the concession area without the written approval of the city. At the end of the rental period, the renter must remove all of its property from the concession area and will no longer have use of the area. Any property not removed by the renter within ten (10) days of the end of the rental period will be removed by the city and stored for up to thirty (30) days. The renter will be responsible for the city's costs incurred in removal and storage of property and must pay such costs before the property will be returned. In addition, the renter will not be allowed to rent any city sports field until such costs are paid in full. The city may use any and all recourse available to collect such costs from the renter. At the end of thirty (30) days, the city will treat any items that have not been returned as abandoned property and will dispose of such property as allowed by law. 
(b)  Any renter of a city sports field must submit with the application the concession area use fee described below. 
(c)  Concession sales shall only be allowed with the appropriate Tarrant County food handler's permit. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-33. - Maintenance. 
During such times that any renter is approved for rental of a particular city sports field, the renter shall be responsible for all routine maintenance and cleaning of the field(s). This shall include, but is not limited to, cleaning up any and all trash, spills or items left in the area; depositing all trash in dumpsters; raking the playing fields after any game or practice; and making sure that concession areas are kept free of spills or spoiled food items that could attract insects or rodents. Renter will be notified in writing of any failure to properly clean and maintain the field and other areas and costs incurred by the city to perform such cleaning or maintenance shall be assessed against the renter. Any subsequent failure to properly clean and maintain the area shall result in termination of the rental agreement and forfeiture of future rental privileges. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-34. - Fees/deposits required. 
(a)  Everman youth associations. 
(1)  Johnson Park Baseball Field. 
a.  Damage deposit. Any Everman youth association renting the four (4) fields at Johnson Park for baseball or softball shall pay a damage deposit in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall be applied to the cost of any damage occurring to the concession area and equipment, fields, stands, parking areas or any other property, structures or facilities during the rental period. Any deposit remaining after offset of such damages shall be refunded to the association within forty-five (45) days after the end of the rental period. If any damage exceeds the damage deposit, the association shall be responsible for payment of any additional costs within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice of such costs. 
b.  Electricity deposit/charges. Any Everman youth association renting the four (4) fields at Johnson Park for baseball or softball shall pay the costs of electricity incurred by the city at the sports field during the rental period. At the time of submission of the application, the association must pay a deposit in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), which will be applied to the cost of electricity used during the rental period. Any deposit amount remaining after offset of the electricity charges shall be refunded to the association within forty-five (45) days after the end of the rental period. 
c.  Per player season fee. Any Everman youth association renting the four (4) fields at Johnson Park for baseball or softball shall be required to pay a one-time per season fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each Everman resident player and ten dollars ($10.00) for each non-Everman resident player on the player roster submitted with the application. This payment must be made to the city prior to the beginning of any practices or games. If the number of players on the roster increases after submission of the application and payment, the association must notify the city and pay the additional fees within five (5) business days of adding the player to the roster. 
d.  Concession area fee. Any Everman youth association renting the four (4) fields at Johnson Park for baseball or softball shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per season for use of the concession area. 
e.  Tournament fee. If any renter schedules a tournament in which participants from outside the renter's association will be playing, a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per team outside of the renter's association will be charged. This fee must be paid prior to the tournament. 
(2)  Clyde Pittman Park Football Field. 
a.  Damage deposit. Any Everman youth association renting the Clyde Pittman Park Football Field shall pay a damage deposit in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall be applied to the cost of any damage occurring to the concession area and equipment, fields, stands, parking areas or any other property, structures or facilities during the rental period. Any deposit remaining after offset of such damages shall be refunded to the association within forty-five (45) days after the end of the rental period. If any damage exceeds the damage deposit, the association shall be responsible for payment of any additional costs within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice of such costs. 
b.  Per player season fee. Any Everman youth association renting the Clyde Pittman Park Football Field shall be required to pay a one-time per season fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each Everman resident player and ten dollars ($10.00) for each non-Everman resident player based on the player roster provided with the application. This payment must be made to the city prior to the beginning of any practices or games. If the number of players on the roster increases after submission of the application and payment, the renter must notify the city and pay the additional fees within five (5) business days of adding the player to the roster. 
c.  Concession area fee. Any Everman youth association renting the Clyde Pittman Park Football Field shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per season for use of the concession area. 
(b)  Other youth associations, entities or persons. 
(1)  Rental fees. Fees for rental of the city sports fields for other youth associations, entities or individuals shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each day game or practice and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each night game or practice plus a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for use of the concession areas. 
(2)  Deposits. In addition, such renters must submit the damage deposits referenced above at the time of application and shall be subject to the same terms as set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-35. - No subleasing. 
Renters shall not allow any other person or entity to use the rented city sports field (except for tournaments pursuant to payment of the tournament fee), or in any other way assign or sublease the city sports field to any third party. Violations of this provision will result in termination of the rental agreement and forfeiture of future rental privileges. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Sec. 14-36. - Rules and regulations. 
The individual signing the application for rental of a city sports field, its administration and any other entity or person associated with the management of such association or entity shall be responsible for ensuring that all coaches, players and spectators comply with the City of Everman Park Use Rules and Regulations set forth in this chapter as well as any other rules and regulations that may be provided to the renter or published to the public from time to time by the city manager. Violation of any of the above-referenced rules and regulations or any local, state or federal laws by any persons under the control of the renter shall result in termination of the rental agreement and forfeiture of future rental privileges. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 7-11-17)  
Chapter 15 - PLANNING AND ZONING[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 15-1. - Filing fees for filing of plats. 
The city secretary shall collect the following fees, in addition to any other required fees, for the filing of plats. The fees listed below shall not be refunded regardless of the action taken by the planning and zoning commission or the city council, whether or not the plats are approved or rejected. 
(1)  Preliminary plats: three hundred dollars (#300.00) plus two dollars ($2.00) per acre; 
(2)  Final plats: four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) plus two dollars ($2.00) per lot. 
(Ord. No. 359, § 1, 8-12-86)  
Sec. 15-2. - Subdivision regulations adopted. 
The regulations attached to Ordinance No. 530 as Exhibit "A" are hereby adopted as the subdivision regulations and design criteria for subdivisions for the City of Everman and are on file in the office of the city secretary and available for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 530, 1-28-03)  
Secs. 15-3—15-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STORAGE OF MOBILE HOMES WITHIN THE CITY 
 
Sec. 15-21. - Defined. 
As used in this article, a "mobile home" means a movable or portable dwelling constructed to be towed by a motor vehicle on its own chasses, and designed without a permanent foundation. It may consist of one (1) or more units that can be telescoped when towed and expanded later for additional capacity, or two (2) or more units, separately towable but designed to be joined into one (1) integral unit. 
(Code 1977, § 13-125) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 15-22. - Permit—Required. 
No person shall store, or permit to be stored, a mobile home on their property without first obtaining a permit to do so for each such mobile home from the building official for the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-121) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11.  
Sec. 15-23. - Same—Fee. 
A fee for each permit issued under this article shall be paid to the city in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1977, § 13-122)  
Sec. 15-24. - Same—Term. 
Permits issued under this article shall be valid for a period of six (6) months and may be revoked at any time if the permit holder violates any section of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 13-123)  
Sec. 15-25. - Right of building official to inspect mobile home and lot it is to be stored on. 
The building official shall have the right to inspect the mobile home and the lot where the mobile home is to be located before issuing a permit. The building official shall not issue a permit if, after inspection, he determines that the storage of the mobile home will be a nuisance, as that term is defined in this Code, or that storage will create a fire hazard or health hazard. 
(Code 1977, § 13-123)  
Chapter 16 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty for Code violations, § 1-7; administration generally, Ch. 2; emergency management, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; municipal court, Ch. 12; offenses, Ch. 13; traffic, Ch. 19. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Chief of police to replace city marshal. 
The office of city marshal is hereby dispensed with, and the office of chief of police is hereby created. 
(Code 1977, § 1-63)  
Sec. 16-2. - Duties of chief of police. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police of this city to enforce all laws of the state and all ordinances of the city; and he shall discharge all of the duties prescribed by law for the city marshal and such other duties as may be imposed upon him by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 1-64)  
Secs. 16-3—16-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 7-56 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-21. - Police department created. 
There is hereby created the police department of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 1-81)  
Sec. 16-22. - Powers and duties of chief. 
The director of the police department shall be the chief of police. The police department shall be composed of the police chief and of such other officers, patrolmen and employees as the city council may determine. The chief of police shall have immediate direction and control of the police department subject to the supervision, rules and regulations and the orders of the city manager. 
(Code 1977, § 1-82)  
Sec. 16-23. - Special police. 
No person, except as otherwise provided by state law or any ordinances passed in pursuance thereof, shall act as special police or special detective. 
(Code 1977, § 1-84)  
Sec. 16-24. - Powers and duties of policemen. 
(a)  The officers constituting the police department of the city shall be and they are hereby invested with all the power and authority given to them as peace officers under the laws of the state in taking cognizance of, and in enforcing, the criminal laws of the state and the ordinances and regulations of the city within the limits of the city. It shall be the duty of each such officer and private to use his best endeavors to prevent the commission within the city of offenses against the laws of the state and against the ordinances and regulations of the city; to observe and enforce all such laws, ordinances and regulations; to detect and arrest offenders against the same; to preserve the good order of the city; and to secure the inhabitants thereof from violence, and property therein from injury. 
(b)  Such policemen shall have no power or authority in civil matters, but they shall execute any criminal warrant or warrant of arrest that may be placed in their hands by the duly constituted authorities of the city. Such policeman shall not receive any fee or other compensation of any services rendered in the performance of his duty, other than the salary paid him by the city, nor shall he receive a fee as a witness in any case arising under the criminal laws of the state, or under the ordinances of regulations of the city and prosecuted in the municipal court of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 1-85)  
Secs. 16-25—16-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ARSON INVESTIGATOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Fire marshal, § 7-81 et seq. 
 
Sec. 16-46. - Office created. 
There is hereby created the office of arson investigator of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 1-161)  
Sec. 16-47. - Duties. 
There is hereby granted to such arson investigator, and such investigator is hereby empowered with, all of the rights, powers and duties of a peace officer, as provided in article 2.12 of the state Code of Criminal Procedure, as well as all of the powers of investigation provided in article 5.45 of the Insurance Code of the state, and all other statutes of the state and by law. 
(Code 1977, § 1-162)  
Sec. 16-48. - Appointed by mayor. 
Such arson investigator of the city shall be appointed by the mayor of the city with the consent and approval of the city council for such terms and under such conditions as desired. 
(Code 1977, § 1-163)  
Sec. 16-49. - Other duties. 
It is further ordered and declared that the person so appointed as arson investigator of the city may have other titles, positions and duties with the fire department of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 1-164)  
Sec. 16-50. - Departmental supervision. 
The arson investigator shall work in the criminal investigation division of the police department under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 1-165)  
Chapter 17 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Flood damage prevention and control, Ch. 8; growth of grass, weeds and uncultivated plants along streets and sidewalks, § 10-42; parks and recreation, Ch. 14. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Materials falling from vehicles, etc. 
Each person who owns or is the operator of a vehicle on any public street or highway in the city shall cause all materials of all kinds to be contained on such vehicle in such a manner as to avoid or prevent such materials from spilling, spewing or leaving the body of such vehicle, while traveling on any public street or highway in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 16-11)  
Sec. 17-2. - Liability insurance, registration and work permit required of persons working in street rights-of-way; exemptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of any construction in street rights-of-way and easements in the city; to construct, repair or modify streets, curb, gutter, waterlines, sewer lines, storm drains or drive approaches without first filing proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) personal injury; obtaining registration with a required fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) renewable January first each year for fifty dollars ($50.00), and obtaining a no cost permit for each occasion from the city prior to commencing work. All work is to be performed to city specifications. 
(b)  Paragraph (a) of this section does not apply to any person who is a regular employee of a regulated utility and who is performing work in conjunction with such person's job, or any person or company employed by the city and performing work in conjunction with such person's job. 
(Ord. No. 366, §§ 1, 2, 9-9-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 462, §§ 1—3, adopted May 24, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification as § 17-3 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 11.  
Sec. 17-3. - Sprinkler systems in city's right-of-way. 
(a)  The construction or installment of sprinkler systems within the city's right-of-way is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  A person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  The city shall not be responsible for repair of or damages to existing sprinkler systems caused by the maintenance of its water lines within the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 462, §§ 1—3, 5-24-96)  
Sec. 17-4. - Operation of motor assisted scooters or pocket bikes. 
(1)  Findings. The city council finds and determines as follows: 
(a)  Prohibiting the use and operation of motor assisted scooters on paths, trails, sidewalks, alleys, streets and highways in the city, except on paths and trails set aside for the exclusive operation of bicycles, is necessary in the interest of safety; 
(b)  Prohibiting the use and operation of pocket bikes on all paths, trails, sidewalks, alleys, streets and highways in the city is necessary in the interest of safety; 
(c)  Requiring children to wear helmets while operating or riding a motor assisted scooter or a pocket bike is necessary in the interest of safety; and 
(d)  It will be advantageous, beneficial and in the best interest of the citizens of Everman to prevent potential traffic hazards and safety hazards resulting from unauthorized use of the paths, trails, sidewalks, alleys, streets and highways in the city by children who fail to wear helmets. 
(2)  Definitions. In this section: 
Child means any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 
Helmet means properly fitted protective headgear that is not structurally damaged and that conforms to the standards of the American National Standards Institute, the American Society for Testing and Materials, the Snell Memorial Foundation or any federal agency having regulatory jurisdiction over bicycle helmets, as applicable, at the time of the manufacture of the helmet. 
Motor assisted scooter shall have the same meaning assigned by Texas Transportation Code, Section 551.301, as it exists or may be amended, and means: 
(a)  A self-propelled device with: 
1.  At least two (2) wheels in contact with the ground during operation; 
2.  A braking system capable of stopping the device under typical operating conditions; 
3.  A gas or electric motor not exceeding forty (40) cubic centimeters; 
4.  A deck designed to allow a person to stand or sit while operating the device; and 
5.  The ability to be propelled by human power alone; but 
(b)  Does not include a pocket bike or a minimotorbike as defined by Texas Transportation Code, Section 551.301. 
Parent means the natural or adoptive parent or court-appointed guardian, or conservator of a child. 
Pocket bike shall mean a "pocket bike" or "minimotorbike" as defined by Texas Transportation Code, Section 551.301, as it exists or may be amended, and means a self-propelled vehicle that is equipped with an electric motor or internal combustion engine having a piston displacement of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, is designed to propel itself with not more than two (2) wheels in contact with the ground, has a seat or saddle for the use of the operator, is not designed for use on a highway, and is ineligible for a certificate of title under Chapter 501 of the Texas Transportation Code. The term does not include any of the following: 
(a)  A moped or motorcycle; 
(b)  An electric bicycle or motor-driven cycle, as defined by Section 541.201 of the Texas Transportation Code; 
(c)  A motorized mobility device, as defined by Section 542.009 of the Texas Transportation Code; 
(d)  An electric personal assistive mobility device, as defined by Section 551.201 of the Texas Transportation Code; 
(e)  A neighborhood electric vehicle, as defined by Section 551.301 of the Texas Transportation Code; or 
(f)  A motor assisted scooter, as defined by Section 551.301 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
Public way or public property means real property owned, leased or controlled by a political subdivision of the State of Texas, a governmental entity or agency, or similar entity, or any property that is publicly owned or maintained or dedicated to public use, including but not limited to, a path, trail, sidewalk, alley, street or highway, and a public park facility. 
Wearing a helmet means that the person has a helmet fastened securely to his/her head with the straps of the helmet securely tightened in the manner intended by the manufacturer to provide maximum protection. 
(3)  Restrictions and prohibitions for motor assisted scooters and pocket bikes, and penalty for violation. 
(a)  Restrictions and prohibitions on locations of use. 
1.  It is unlawful to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter on any path, trail, sidewalk, alley, street or highway within the city, except on a path or trail set aside for the exclusive operation of bicycles. 
2.  It is unlawful to operate or ride a pocket bike on any sidewalk, path, trail, alley, street or highway within the city. 
3.  It is unlawful for a parent to allow or permit a child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter on any path, trail, sidewalk, alley, street or highway within the city, except on a path or trail set aside for the exclusive operation of bicycles. 
4.  It is unlawful for a parent to allow or permit a child to operate or ride a pocket bike on any path, trail, sidewalk, alley, street or highway within the city. 
5.  It is presumed that a parent allowed a child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter or a pocket bike in a restricted or prohibited area. 
(b)  Penalty. 
1.  A person who violates any provision of subsection (3)(a), above, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
2.  The purpose of this subsection (3) is to promote safety and discourage the use of motor assisted scooters or pocket bikes in unsafe areas. The courts may consider deferred dispositions under the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as it exists or may be amended, whenever the circumstances warrant deferred dispositions. 
3.  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the motor assisted scooter or pocket bike was not being operated or ridden upon public property or a public way at the time of the alleged offense. 
(4)  Helmets required; penalty for failure to wear helmet. 
(a)  Helmet required. 
1.  It is unlawful for any child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter or a pocket bike unless the child is wearing a helmet. 
2.  It is unlawful for a parent to allow or permit a child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter or a pocket bike unless the child is wearing a helmet. 
3.  It is presumed that a parent allowed a child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter or a pocket bike without a helmet. 
4.  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the motor assisted scooter or pocket bike was not being operated or ridden upon public property or a public way at the time of the alleged offense. 
(b)  Penalty. 
1.  A person who violates any provision of subsection (4)(a), above, requiring helmets, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined an amount not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) upon the first conviction and an amount not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) upon the second and each subsequent conviction. 
2.  The municipal court shall dismiss a charge against a child and/or parent for a first offense under subsection (4)(a) upon receiving proof that: 
a.  The defendant acquired a helmet for the child who was operating or riding the motor assisted scooter or pocket bike in violation of subsection (4)(a); and 
b.  The defendant acquired the helmet on or before the tenth day after receiving the citation for the violation. 
3.  If the charge against a person is dismissed under subsection (b)2. of this subsection, a later conviction for a violation of subsection (4)(a) shall be considered a second or subsequent conviction for purposes of subsection (b)1. of this subsection. 
4.  The purpose of this subsection (4) is to promote safety and encourage the use of helmets. The courts may consider deferred dispositions under the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as it exists or may be amended, whenever the circumstances warrant deferred disposition. 
(5)  Savings; repealing clause. This section shall be cumulative of all provisions of ordinances and the Code of the City of Everman, Texas, except where the provisions of this section are in direct conflict with the provisions of such ordinances and Code, in which event the conflicting provisions of such ordinances and Code are hereby repealed. 
(6)  Penalty clause. Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined as set forth herein. Each unlawful act or continuing day's violation under this section shall constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this section shall not preclude the City of Everman from filing suit to enjoin the violation. The City of Everman retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 557, §§ 1—5, 7, 7-12-05)  
Sec. 17-5—17-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 
 
Sec. 17-21. - Permit to open required. 
Any person desiring to open any street, alley or sidewalk for the purpose of making connections to any water or sanitary sewer system or for any other purpose in the city or to alter or repair any waterlines or house or main or lateral sewer lines, or for any other reason, shall first make application to the city secretary or his authorized representative, and receive in writing a permit to open such street, alley or sidewalk for such purpose or purposes as the term of the permit shall specify. 
(Code 1977, § 16-1) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous regulations, Ch. 11.  
Sec. 17-22. - Restoration of street, alley or sidewalk. 
(a)  Upon the expiration time named in the permit or sooner, if the use of the streets, alleys, avenues or public grounds as provided therein is no longer necessary, the permittee shall clear the street, alley or sidewalk of all obstructions. 
(b)  Specifications for restoring streets, alleys or sidewalks are as follows: 
(1)  Dirt street or alley. Any ditch shall be well-stamped in six-inch layers, and in case of settlement, the party holding the permit agrees to maintain the ditch for a reasonable length of time. 
(2)  Gravel street or alley. Any ditch shall be well-tamped in six-inch layers to a point nine (9) inches below the surface of the street, after which one (1) foot of good road gravel will be tamped in until level with the surface of the existing street. The party holding the permit agrees to maintain the cut for a reasonable length of time. 
(3)  Asphalt-treated gravel streets. Any ditch shall be taken care of as set out in this subsection and in addition the cut shall be finished by hand-pouring approximately .6 of a gallon of 90-100 penetration asphalt followed by a covering of what is ordinarily termed chat or torpedo gravel. 
(4)  Paved streets. Any ditch shall be flooded and filled with a good quality backfill gravel and tamped down to a point six (6) inches below the top of the existing concrete base and then filled with six (6) inches of a 1:6 mixture of concrete. After four (4) days time, a surface shall be applied corresponding to the existing surface on the street. 
(5)  Other streets. No street, road, or thoroughfare in the city that has been modified to conform to semipermanent design shall be cut or opened by the permittee, but the permittee shall be required to drill, core or jack through the subgrade at a depth to be determined by the city engineer. However, if such procedure is deemed impractical by reason of rock, utilities, underground construction or terrain and a cut or opening is made, all backfill materials shall be of selected mineral aggregate and cement in proportions of 27 to 1, properly compacted and covered with a three-inch concrete slab sub-grade. 
(6)  Sidewalks, gutters and driveways. Any ditch shall be flooded and filled with a good quality of backfill gravel after which a concrete surface shall be applied that meets with specifications for concrete sidewalks, gutters and drivewalks, as required by the city. 
(7)  Inspection. Any and all of the work mentioned in this subsection shall be done under the direction of, and shall be satisfactory to, the city engineer. The holder of a permit shall notify the city engineer twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time the backfill will be made, and a city inspector shall be present at the time the work is done. However, this will in no way relieve the permit holder from his responsibility for maintenance due to failure of the repaired cut. 
(8)  Notification to restore; payment for costs. If such opening or excavation is not refilled and restored as herein provided and approved by the city engineer or his authorized representative, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to notify the permittee in writing to refill and restore same. If the permittee shall fail to refill and restore the same within three (3) days after issuance of such notice, the city engineer shall immediately proceed to have the opening or excavation refilled and restore the street, alley or sidewalk to its previous condition at the cost of the permittee and to pay for the same either out of the aforementioned cash deposit, or demand payment of the cost of such restoration from the permittee and his surety in cases where the permittee has filed a surety bond as provided in this chapter. In cases where a cash deposit was made, whatever amount of the deposit may remain after the payment of the cost of restoration is made, shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(9)  Refund of deposit; permit status. If the permittee shall refill and restore the street or alley to its previous condition and same is approved by the city engineer, the aforementioned cash deposit shall be returned to permittee upon authorization by the city engineer. If any permittee shall fail to refill and restore any street, alley or sidewalk, no further permit shall be issued the permittee by the city secretary until the excavation shall have been refilled and restored and the cost of same has been fully paid. 
(Code 1977 § 16-3)  
Sec. 17-23. - Convenience and safety of the public. 
(a)  The permit holder shall not cut or open more than one-half of the roadway at a time in order to maintain the flow of traffic at all times. However, in an emergency, or with the permission of the city engineer, the total width of roadway may be cut or opened, provided that barricades are placed at the first intersection each way from the cut and suitable detour signs are erected. 
(b)  If a cut or opening is left after sundown, a barricade must be placed on both sides of the cut and a suitable flare or flares shall be placed in front of each barricade. The barricades and flares shall be furnished by the permit holder. 
(c)  It is understood that the permit holder shall be responsible for the safety of the public and shall be held fully liable for accidents and for damages that might be caused by the cut until same has been approved and accepted by the city engineer or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1977, § 16-4)  
Sec. 17-24. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall dig up or cut any street, alley or sidewalk in the city without first having secured a permit as provided in this chapter or who fails and refuses to comply with the specifications in backfilling and restoration of such streets, alleys and sidewalks, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-7. 
(b)  In case of any willful violation of any of the terms and provisions of this article, the city, in addition to imposing the penalties provided in paragraph (a), may institute any appropriate action or proceedings in any court having proper jurisdiction to restrain, correct or abate such violation. Further the definition of any violation of the terms of this article as a misdemeanor shall not preclude the city from invoking the civil remedies given it by the laws of the state, but shall be cumulative and subject to prosecutions as prescribed in paragraph (a), for such violations. 
(Code 1977, § 16-5)  
Secs. 17-25—17-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TREES ON PUBLIC LANDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 426, §§ 1—14, adopted June 4, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as Art. III, §§ 17-31—17-44 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, Ch. 14. 
 
Sec. 17-31. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Street trees is herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between the curb, pavement line, and the property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
Park trees is herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 1, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-32. - Creation and establishment of a tree board. 
There is hereby created and established a city tree board for the city, which shall consist of the same persons who are members of the park board so that the park board shall also serve as the city tree board, (herein referred to as the "board"). 
(Ord. No. 426, § 2, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-33. - Compensation. 
Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 3, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-34. - Duties and responsibilities. 
It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel, and develop and/or update annually a written plan for the care, preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal, or disposition of trees and shrubs in public ways, streets, and alleys. Such a plan will be presented to the city council for approval. 
The board, under the supervision and with the approval of the city manager, shall be responsible for the planting, pruning, and removal of all trees located within the street rights-of-way, easements, alleys, and parks of the city. The owner of land abutting on any street may, when acting within the provisions of this article, prune, spray, plant, or remove, trees in that part of the street abutting his land. Permission of the board shall only be required when the owner of the abutting property intends to deviate from the rules and regulations contained in this article. 
The board, when requested by the city council or the city manager, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report, and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 4, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-35. - Species size classes. 
[The types of species size classes of trees dealt with in this article are as follows:] 
  Small Trees 	  Large Trees 
Redbud 	Live Oak 
Hawthorn 	Bur Oak 
Flowering Dogwood 	Red Oak (Shumard) 
Crepe Myrtle 	Water Oak 
Japanese Black Pine 	Chinese Pistachio 
Gum Elastic 	Cedar Elm 
Arizona Cypress 	Southern Magnolia 
Eastern Red 	Pecan 
Mesquite 	Sweetgum 
Mexican Plum 	Greenash 
Callary Pear 	Pinus Elderica 
Bradford Pear 	
 
(Ord. No. 426, § 5, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-36. - Spacing. 
The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 17-35 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following (without approval of the tree board); small trees, twenty (20) feet; and large trees, forty (40) feet. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 6, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-37. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 17-35 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: Small trees, two (2) feet and large trees, four (4) feet in accordance with existing city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 7, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-38. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
No street tree shall be planted closer than twenty (20) feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fireplug. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 8, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-39. - Utilities. 
No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 17-35 of this article may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
Utility companies franchised by the city may remove or trim trees which potentially endanger public safety and welfare by interfering with the continuance of electric service, except that where such trees are on owner occupied properties developed for one-family use, complete removal of such trees shall be at the option of the property owner. 
The right, license, privilege and permission is hereby granted to the electric company, its successors and assigns, to trim trees upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city, so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires or cables of the electric company. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 9, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-40. - Public tree care. 
The city shall have the right to plant, trim, spray, preserve, and remove trees, plants, shrubs, within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure safety when servicing city utilities or to preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The board under the supervision and with the approval of the city manager may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is located on public property or municipal utility easement, which by reasons of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other pest. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 10, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-41. - Trimming corner clearance. 
Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall trim the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the street or right-of-way. The city shall have the right to trim any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. Such trimming is to be confined to the area immediately above the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 11, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-42. - Interference with board. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the board or its authorized agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees and park trees as authorized in this article. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 12, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-43. - Review by city council. 
The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the board to the city council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 13, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 17-44. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction or a plea of guilty, shall be subject to a fine in an amount not to exceed the maximum allowed by law. Each day may constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 426, § 14, 6-4-91)  
Chapter 18 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:
